column1: The starting point of this seminar is the widespread use of the internet and subsequently the way in which new media technologies have influenced user and producer interaction in the creative industries.  The seminar offers a critical analysis of various theoretical perspectives on audience engagement. Internet positivists underline the value of actively participating audience members – engaged audience members can co-create, help with promotion activities and are a key asset for   organizations in the creative industries in retaining a sustainable business model. Cultural critics are more skeptical towards audience engagement – especially when it comes to content creation. They believe that user-generated content could possibly undermined our culture. On a more practical level, many organizations struggle with engaging their audiences. Although it is sometimes assumed that online all users are active and engaged participants, in reality, there is a participation gap. Most people are lurkers and will not necessarily participate or engage in a more active way.

This seminar provides a state-of-the-art overview of the way engagement has been conceptualized   in academia, how its understanding has developed from a more passive form of engagement to a more active form of engagement, and how particularly new media technologies offer new tools to reshape the audience-producer relationship through engagement. We will focus on topics that are related to societal and cultural aspects of engagement, such as the possibilities of and limits to self- expression, the different levels of engagement and their motivational aspects, and the way engagement is incorporated into the strategies of organizations in the creative industries. During this seminar, you will be challenged to apply your theoretical knowledge to a practical case in which you will advise an organization in the creative industries about a specific problem concerning audience engagement.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyze recent and future trends in audience engagement
• Reflect in a critical way on the claims made by academics from various perspectives
• Take up and defend various positions in academic discourse
• Analyze an empirical case independently and in a team
• Compare and contrast various perspectives in a team and work towards a common line of reasoning
• Solve a challenge based on a communal interpretation of academic literature
• Collaborate to formulate a practical advice for an organization
• Jointly present a solution to an organization in an engaging way

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99976,2021,Audience Studies: Current Perspectives,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TL Koren'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

After having been familiarized with classic academic literature on the reception of culture and media in previous courses, students now dive into current perspectives and approaches in the field of audience studies. We explore the state of the art in this academic paradigm, looking at various types of audiences and an array of media forms. How do audiences use and interpret media (content) in today’s ever more mediatized world? Which role does music play in people’s everyday life? How does gaming effect players? Why do people watch reality TV? How do we interpret Hollywood films around the world? And how do we effectively research these questions?
We discuss theoretical foundations and relevant concepts but also take a hands-on approach, in which students are encouraged to analyze and present case studies of their own interest.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and approaches in the field of audience studies;
• Current developments in the reception and use of media

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of audience reception of media;
• Analyze and critically reflect upon current research in the field of audience studies;
• Coherently present the discussed material, both verbal and in written form;
• Effectively research case studies of audience reception in a wide variety of media cultures

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: ‘Ik ben mijzelf een grote vraag geworden’ zegt Augustinus (354-430) in zijn autobiografische Belijdenissen als hij als een van de eersten in de geschiedenis nadenkt over het menselijk geheugen. Dit werk zou van groot belang worden als bron voor latere filosofen, zoals Augustinus’ denken over de ideale staat in De stad Gods van invloed zou zijn op latere theorieën over de politiek en economie.

Aan Augustinus’ denken over filosofische, theologische, psychologische of economische kwesties ging evenwel steeds een fundamenteel inzicht vooraf, zoals ook uit het bovenstaand citaat duidelijk wordt. Een mens is beperkt: niet alleen in zijn rationaliteit maar ook in zijn moraliteit. Daarom rijzen vragen: komen mensen alleen door speculatie tot kennis en wijsheid? En als dit niet het geval blijkt omdat zij onderkend hebben dat hun verstand ontoereikend is en hun taal te beperkt om uit te drukken wat zij denken: hoe komen zij dan tot inzicht in wat wezenlijk goed, waar en mooi is? Houdt inzicht verband met een levensvoering waarin deugden als ‘gematigdheid’ of ‘liefde’ prevaleren als weg naar inzicht?

De wijze waarop Augustinus de onvolkomenheid van mensen en hun taligheid postuleert lijkt hem tot voorloper van opvattingen over de ‘bounded rationality’ en ‘bounded morality’ te maken. Maar - in weerwil van zijn kennis van alle menselijke beperktheden – blijkt hij ook deugden als de moderantia (gematigheidheid) en de caritas (liefde) als opmaten tot inzicht te onderkennen.

In dit college worden cruciale teksten van Augustinus in chronologische volgorde gelezen om de ontwikkelingen in zijn denken op het spoor te komen over (1) de ontoereikendheid van de mens én (2) de menselijke levensorde, die idealiter door deugden wordt bepaald en daardoor tot ware wijsheid leidt.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Aan het eind van de cursus hebben de studenten inzicht in de ontwikkelingen in het denken van Augustinus over (1) de ontoereikendheid van het menselijk verstand en van de beperktheid van taal, (2) de levensorde (ordo vitae) als weg naar inzicht in de essentie van het leven en (3) de samenhang tussen beide.

Zij zijn in staat gebleken in een paper (1) een bepaald aspect van deze drie zwaartepunten in het denken van Augustinus uit te diepen in het licht van zijn bronnen, (2) hierop kritisch te reflecteren en (3) Augustinus’ denken over dit bepaalde aspect te actualiseren.</body>

column1: In this course focusing on economic and political history approaches, students are offered a new conceptual framework for understanding when and how environmental and biological hazards turned into disasters – and when and how this was prevented. Students learn that history is of great value for helping us understand the long-term economic and political consequences that very short-term hazards could create; and vice-versa, students learn that hazards, shocks and disasters can enrich our study of past societies by opening a window to facets of society hidden from view during “normal times”.

During the course, students focus on classifications and concepts such as “vulnerability”, “resilience”, “adaptation”, and “risk”, and apply these to their own historical case studies, which form the basis of a research proposal that will become the foundation of their BA thesis. Typical kinds of questions that students might want to address using explicitly historical approaches include: how do disasters affect state control of citizens, and how do disasters affect citizens trust towards governments? Do disasters make societies more unequal or equal? Who is to blame for disasters? Do disasters bring communities together or lead to discord? How disasters affect the relationships between states? Are we at greater risk in the age of the Anthropocene, or are we now more protected than in the past via science and technology?

• Students will present their research ideas orally.

column1: The Thesis & Internship, including the thesis proposal, constitutes the heart of Block 3 through 5 of the MSc BA Business Analytics & Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research that applies analytics to one of the functional domains (‘profiles’) in business administration (marketing, supply chain management/operations, finance, accounting, business information management).

The thesis is perceived as a proof of students’ academic level of thinking, especially a proof of intellectual and analytical craftsmanship. During the thesis trajectory, BAM students study a field in business administration in more depth. The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, train their capabilities in analytics and problem solving, improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and develop a personal profile.

The thesis trajectory is followed in combination with an internship at a company or non-profit organization. This provides students with actual problems and a problem context including several stakeholders. It also means that students get exposed to issues such as time pressure, decision cycles, legal constraints, and ethical aspects.

The objective of the thesis trajectory is to deliver not just an “answer” to a single problem instance, but rather a proof of concept or analytics solution that can be applied to a class of problem instances.

As part of the Job Market & Negotiation Skills course students have searched for an internship. By the beginning of February, they hand in their thesis proposal, which outlines the problem they will study and the big picture analytics-based approach to solving it. Using an online system, they submit their proposal, indicating the chosen field of business administration. Due to limited supervision capacity, each domain will impose a certain capacity limit, which can be consulted online. Students are assigned a coach (primary supervisor) and co-reader. They will help the student shape their proposal and supervise the student throughout the Internship & Thesis trajectory. The thesis counts for 16 ECTS and is part of the GPA.
Deadlines for handing in thesis will be announced later.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In order to successfully complete the MSc BA Business Analytics & Management (henceforth BAM) students have to follow a master thesis trajectory. In the BAM master the thesis will be based on an internship .
The learning objectives of the Master Thesis are to enable students to:
2.    Systematically follow the research cycle for a business analytics project.
3.    Demonstrate core knowledge on the interaction between an organisation and its broader environment including stakeholders.
4.    Demonstrate knowledge on analytical methods and core models in the chosen business field of specialization.

5.    Generate an effective and coherent approach to solving ill-defined business problems which have no standard solution and understand the managerial implications given the trade-off between appropriateness for the problem and practicality.
6.    Implement advanced analytics solutions given time pressure, decision cycles, legal constraints, and ethical aspects of the thesis/internship context.
7.    Demonstrate effective skills in communicating with different stakeholders.
8.    Present research and findings in a sound scientific report.
9.    Demonstrate critical reflection of your ethical responsibility as well as your influence, abilities, and limitations to instill these ethical values on others.</body>

column1: The BIM Company-Based Research Project (CRP) allows students to replace one free elective course in the program with a full-time thesis / research internship for one of the elective blocks (minimum of 168 hours). During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to continue working part-time and follow the remaining electives.

The BIM CRP should seek to combine the writing of the thesis with an internship at a company during one of the elective blocks (Blocks, 3, 4, or 5). It is therefore important that the internship is related to the thesis and students will need to decide on an internship in consultation with their thesis coach and the master thesis coordinator. Students must be able to show that the internship will allow them to collect company-specific data (for that specific company), and that it is essential for their thesis project.
The CRP will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach, company supervisor and master thesis coordinator.

If a student opts for the CRP, it will count as a free elective for 6 EC. This will give them the opportunity to work exclusively within the company for a period of 7 weeks. Thesis internships may be agreed for a longer period of time, but a minimum of 168 hours is expected and a maximum of 6 ECTS is credited. During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to work part-time and follow the remaining electives.

THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR BIM STUDENTS ONLY. In order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other BIM Programme Electives! Please do not select this elective if you have not signed a contract yet.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing the BIM Company-Based Research Project, students should be able to:

column2: • Design and manage a small project to research or solve a practical business problem by using established techniques and insights of research;
• Analyse specific challenges an organization is facing in the contemporary context;
• Conduct a practical research project that addresses these challenges;
• Present a well-structured, well-argued research project, its findings, and your own recommendations;
• Carry out a project under the supervision of a company manager.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The BIM Honours Programme offers the most talented and motivated students in the MSc BIM program a challenging extracurricular course in BIM research and practice. Participation is by invitation only. A limited group of 25-30 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd, 4th, and 5th block of their studies. Selected students are the best performing students of the MSc in BIM programme. The small group size ensures that students have many opportunities for interaction with faculty members and participating companies.

The programme features involvement from multiple companies. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation. Cooperation is sought with external partners, who introduce a series of challenges that students need to complete (e.g. consultancy project, data analytics challenge, business process training).

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Business Information Management. The first step in the selection process will be a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS). In the second step in the selection process, the highest ranking students will be asked to submit a motivation letter.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The honours class in Business Information Management puts excellent students in close contact with the latest advancements in research and practice. The course is designed to complement the MSc course portfolio by offering more in-depth training in selected areas of particular interest. The programme is also offering networking opportunities and contacts with executives and companies.

column1: During the year you will participate in a structured master thesis trajectory. You will start in September, during the core courses, to familiarize yourself with the research being done at our department and the relevant academic literature and topics available. Staff involved in this MSc will present their current research projects, and you will be invited to link your master thesis to one of these projects. Before Christmas you will decide on a final topic and be assigned a coach who is an expert in the subject area chosen. Early January a thesis clinic will provide you with the foundation that you will need to complete your thesis successfully. In February you will deliver your research proposal after which you will implement your research question and finalize your thesis before the summer. Staff and researchers will provide assistance by coaching you through the entire master thesis process.
The following themes are examples of possible BIM Master Thesis topics:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The writing of your master thesis – the report of your scientific study – is the most important part of the Business Information Management programme. The master thesis is your opportunity to show your potential as a next generation manager. During this period, you will interact with internationally-recognized companies and well-known researchers in the field of Business Information Management.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100624,2021,BIM Research Methods,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Gutt', 'dr. D Tsekouras', 'prof.dr.ir. HWGM van Heck']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today’s economy, data-driven decision making in firms increasingly replaces decision based on gut feelings. As data is becoming increasingly available for firms from sources both internal and external, the need to understand methods to process and analyze data grows steadily.

Therefore, this course will equip students with the necessary tools to extract knowledge from data to succeed in their master theses and ultimately conduct their own research. To this end, students will be introduced to the fundamentals of selected empirical research methods (case studies and econometrics) and selected types of data provenance (observational, experimental, and survey data). Understanding these methods and data types will be essential for the students’ success in their master theses and, not only but especially, when considering pursuing an academic career after their master’s degree in form of a PhD. Students will have hands-on experience with data to acquire expertise in solving practical data-related issues. These skills are not only crucial to the success in this course but are valuable assets in other courses covering data analytics in their master’s programme as well as in their professional lives, of course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will provide students with a basic understanding of different methodological issues, including a basic understanding of:

column2: • Describe the basic research methodologies in the BIM field
• Explain how to decide on a research methodology in the domain of empirical research
• Understand how to design a survey
• Clean, organize, and analyze data in R
• Perform basic univariate and multivariate econometric analyses
• Justify certain research methods for the research question at hand
• Evaluate the difference in performance of different statistical methods and discuss advantages and drawbacks of methods

column1: One of the reasons companies hire university graduates, is because of their academic posture. This includes a critical attitude towards what is presented as “the truth”, the ability to assess the quality of research presented to them, and the competence to study a phenomenon in a structured way. These same qualities are required of you as you design and execute your Master thesis project. This course will focus on the basics of conducting sound scientific research and writing a good master thesis. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: • Create (plan & set‐up) a solid scientific research project and understand the key considerations in designing and implementing it.
• Formulate a sound research objective and research question for a research project in Business Information Management.
• Critically evaluate research in the area of Business Information Management and related fields.
• Conduct a literature review and collect, organize and interpret academic literature.
• Comprehend the research methodologies and develop the ability make an informed decision for a research methodology, appropriate for their research objective.
• Understand the foundations of academic writing and develop the vocabulary required to communicate their research.
• Write a sound proposal for an academic study.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98978,2021,BSc Project Analytical Decision-Makers,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, you will work on a research question in teams of four students under the supervision of a supervisor. The supervisor is your main contact during this course, whereas the track coordinator and course coordinator will primarily aid the supervisors.

This course builds on the Advanced Research Methods (ARM) course, meaning you are expected to apply this knowledge to your Bachelor Project. The core of the project is research, and what type of research will vary by track. This project follows the following steps of a research cycle: A managerial problem, a knowledge question, review of evidence, research design, data collection, data analysis, answer to the question, recommendation to management. “Management” should be read as “stakeholder from practice”. The outcome can be a design, hypothesis test, conceptual framework, and in all cases is translated into an answer to a managerial problem. The data can be quantitative or qualitative, primary or secondary, empirical or simulated.

Via four different assignments you will work on your Bachelor Project. Assignment 1 and 2 will focus on the Critical Synthesis of Literature and the Project Design. Assignment 3 and 4 will follow with the Research Results and the Conclusion. Each assignment is graded. After each assignment, feedback will be provided by the supervisor. For a schematic overview of the course and how it is linked to ARM, we refer to Figure 1 on the next page.

In this course you work in a team of four students. The team is enrolled in a “Theme”, a research topic offered by a supervisor within your track. The supervisor of the Theme will be the one who coaches you throughout the process and provides you with feedback on your assignments.

To successfully complete the Bachelor Project, we assume that students participate in Advanced Research Methods (B3101) in parallel or have already completed this course. Moreover, we assume that students have active knowledge of the concepts covered in Research Project. Lastly, the course builds on a lot of knowledge that you should have acquired in previous methods-related courses (e.g., statistics, mathematics). It is your responsibility to dust off this knowledge. Look at material from these courses when things are not top of mind. Do not expect your supervisor to act like a tutor on such topics.

You will apply the knowledge gained from the ARM course and you will learn what these principles mean by applying them in your own project. Your Bachelor Project in this course consists of completing four assignments. After having completed your Bachelor Project, you should be able to:

column2: • Collect and critically assess academic and professional literature on a specific topic
• Write a critical synthesis of the academic and professional literature
• Identify a relevant managerial problem and translate the managerial question into a research question
• Design a research project that can be executed in the available timeframe
• Collect and analyse data that is needed to answer the research question
• Present research results and defend the choices you have made
• Critically evaluate and discuss your research results

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In het eerste studiejaar start het CA-onderwijs (Communicatie en Attitude). Hierbij staan de rollen ‘communicator’, ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ en ‘academicus’ centraal. Bij de rol ‘communicator’ gaat het onder andere om open en respectvolle communicatie met patiënten. De student kan een goede anamnese afnemen, waarbij hij relevante informatie krijgt van de patiënt, actief luistert en begrip en empathie toont. De rol ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ gaat onder andere over het leveren van patiëntenzorg op integere, oprechte en betrokken wijze. De student herkent ethische dilemma’s en kan omgaan met diversiteit in patiëntenachtergrond. De rol ‘academicus’ houdt onder andere in dat de student staat is om te reflecteren op het eigen handelen. De student kent de grenzen van het eigen kunnen en handelt daarnaarZie voor meer informatie de studentenhandleiding van PKV-CA jaar 1</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Het onderwijs in praktische klinische vaardigheden (PKV) bestaat uit drie onderdelen: PKV-MT (medische technieken), PKV-MA (medische anamnese) en PKV-CA (communicatie en attitude). Het CA-onderwijs begint in Bachelor 1, PKV-MT en PKV-MA starten in Bachelor 2. In Bachelor 3 worden CA, MA en MT ook gecombineerd in de lessen APC (Arts Patiënt Contact). Daarnaast leert de student acute hulp te verlenen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102005,2021,Ba1 Integratietoets,Nederlands,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. A. van t Spijker', 'G. Elshout', 'P.C.J. de Laat', 'R.A. van der Wolf, BA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Iedere vraag is in principe gekoppeld aan een klacht van een patiënt, zogenaamde casusvragen. Voorafgaand aan de toets, minimaal één week van tevoren, ontvangt de student per casus een korte beschrijving van de patiënt en zijn klacht. Dit ‘patiëntvignet’ bestaat uit de volgende informatie:
·          de rol, bijvoorbeeld: je bent huisarts
·          de klachtpresentatie, bijvoorbeeld: sinds vanochtend kortademig

Onderdeel van klinisch redeneren is ook het kunnen inpassen van ontwikkelingen in de wetenschappelijke literatuur. Het beoordelen van resultaten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek op kwaliteit en waarde maakt daarom deel uit van de integratietoets. Dit aspect wordt met name in het eerste bachelorjaar uitvoerig getoetst. Ook wordt leerstof uit de academisch beroepsgebonden vakken, zoals ethiek, filosofie, geschiedenis en recht getoetst, evenals leerstof uit de lijn normale psychologie.
De integratietoets is een gecombineerd schriftelijk tentamen met zowel gesloten als open vragen.
Er zijn twee tentamenmogelijkheden per jaar. Voor de beschrijving van de cesuur wordt verwezen naar de Regels en Richtlijnen voor de Examens.
Meer informatie over deze toets en voorbeelden van toetsvragen staat in de handleiding Klinisch Redeneren van het betreffende bachelorjaar.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: De integratietoets is erop gericht het vermogen tot klinisch redeneren te toetsen, en is de afsluitende jaartoets van de lijn Klinisch Redeneren. In deze toets herhaalt de student zijn verworven (bio)medische kennis uit de thema’s gecombineerd met de kennis over vaardigheden en integreert hij deze kennis door deze in een (nieuwe) klinische context toe te passen. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De lijn 'Professionele Ontwikkeling' bestaat in de bachelor uit de volgende onderdelen:

column2: Coaching - Tijdens de bachelor voer je een aantal keer een gesprek met een coach. Hierover ontvang je in de loop van het jaar meer informatie.
Bachelorverklaring - In het begin van jaar 1 leggen alle studenten tijdens een gezamenlijke bijeenkomst de bachelorverklaring af.
Zelfportret - Een zelfstudieopdracht waarin je een zelfportret maakt. Meer informatie in het themaboek van thema Ba1A.

column1: De gezondheidszorg en het medische beroep zijn in de afgelopen jaren flink veranderd. Zo is er bij de populatie sprake van een toename van chronische ziekten en co-morbiditeit bij steeds ouder wordende patiënten. Er is een toenemende complexiteit en specialisatie in de zorg en een toegenomen diversiteit aan patiënten en zorgverleners. Daarbij is de zorg technologischer en kennisintensiever geworden. Ook de rol van patiënten is veranderd; waar patiënten zorg eerder passief ontvingen, beslissen ze nu actief mee en voeren ze de eigen regie.

De opleiding Geneeskunde moet zo zijn ingericht dat deze toekomstige artsen goed voorbereidt op werken in de snel veranderende gezondheidszorg. Daarbij is het van belang dat artsen kunnen zorg dragen voor een houdbaar gezondheidszorgsysteem in de toekomst. Teamwork, een effectieve samenwerking tussen artsen onderling, tussen artsen en andere zorgverleners en tussen artsen en de patiënt en zijn/haar familie en omgeving, staat hierbij centraal.

Het Erasmus MC heeft dan ook de ambitie om basisartsen op te leiden die onderscheidend zijn als teamspelers, die effectief kunnen samenwerken om optimale (kwalitatief hoogwaardige, veilige en doelmatige) zorg te kunnen leveren in samenspraak met de patiënt en preventie in de praktijk te laten slagen. In het curriculum wordt daarom meer aandacht besteed aan (interprofessioneel) samenwerken, veiligheid, kwaliteit en doelmatigheid van zorg, patiëntgerichte zorg, preventie en een populatiegerichte benadering van ziekte en gezondheid. Dit onderwijs vormt de lijn Samenwerken voor Optimale Zorg en Preventie (SOZP).

Dit onderwijs biedt de gelegenheid je optimaal te kunnen ontwikkelen in de competenties behorend bij de CanMEDS rollen Samenwerker, Organisator en Gezondheidsbevorderaar en op het gebied van de Erasmusarts eindtermen, die vallen onder de clusters Klinische en beroepsgebonden vaardigheden en Maatschappelijke verantwoordelijkheid: zorgvisie en preventie.
De lijn SOZP bestaat uit twee aandachtsgebieden:

column2: Samenwerken en Veiligheid (SV). Dit aandachtsgebied beslaat onder andere de onderwerpen (interprofessioneel) samenwerken, kwaliteit en veiligheid van zorg, patiëntgerichtheid en shared decision making.
Zorgvisie en Preventie (ZP). Dit aandachtsgebied beslaat onder andere de onderwerpen kostenbewustzijn, doelmatigheid en preventie.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De opleiding Geneeskunde leidt basisartsen op waarvan het profiel is beschreven in het Raamplan 2009. De eindtermen van de opleiding zijn vertaald naar eindtermen per curriculumonderdeel, per opleidingsjaar, welke de basis vormen voor de inrichting van het onderwijs en toetsing.
Voor het aandachtsgebied van Samenwerken en Veiligheid (SV) zijn voor de bachelor de volgende twee eindtermen als uitgangspunten genomen:

column2: De student kan op doeltreffende wijze samenwerken met collega’s, andere zorgverleners, patiënten en/of cliënten en hun naasten om veilige zorg te leveren.
De student kan bijdragen aan interdisciplinaire teams op het gebied van zorg, onderzoek en onderwijs.

column1: Voor het aandachtsgebied van Zorgvisie en Preventie (ZP) zijn voor de bachelor de volgende twee eindtermen als uitgangspunten genomen:

column2: De student kan risicovolle determinanten herkennen en naar aanleiding daarvan adequaat handelen op zowel individueel, groeps- en maatschappelijk niveau.
De student kan actief bijdragen aan verbeteringen van de kwaliteit, veiligheid en doelmatigheid van de gezondheidszorg en maatschappelijke opvang.

column1: De specifieke eindtermen voor de lijn SOZP voor het eerste bachelorjaar staan hieronder weergegeven. Dit is het vereiste beheersingsniveau dat aan het eind van het eerste bachelorjaar voor de lijn SOZP van je wordt verwacht en waarop je wordt getoetst.

column2: De student heeft inzicht in de factoren die essentieel zijn voor het functioneren in een team in het kader van veilige zorg.
De student kan feedback geven en vragen op aspecten van samenwerkvaardigheden.
De student kan reflecteren op zijn/haar eigen sterke en zwakke kanten in het samenwerken.
De student kan de determinanten die de gezondheid kunnen beïnvloeden benoemen.
De student kan de mogelijke niveaus van preventie (primaire, secundaire en tertiaire) benoemen.
De student kan de werking en financiering van de gezondheidszorg op hoofdlijnen beschrijven.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In het eerste studiejaar start het CA-onderwijs (Communicatie en Attitude). Hierbij staan de rollen ‘communicator’, ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ en ‘academicus’ centraal. Bij de rol ‘communicator’ gaat het onder andere om open en respectvolle communicatie met patiënten. De student kan een goede anamnese afnemen, waarbij hij relevante informatie krijgt van de patiënt, actief luistert en begrip en empathie toont. De rol ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ gaat onder andere over het leveren van patiëntenzorg op integere, oprechte en betrokken wijze. De student herkent ethische dilemma’s en kan omgaan met diversiteit in patiëntenachtergrond. De rol ‘academicus’ houdt onder andere in dat de student staat is om te reflecteren op het eigen handelen. De student kent de grenzen van het eigen kunnen en handelt daarnaarZie voor meer informatie de studentenhandleiding van PKV-CA jaar 1</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Het onderwijs in praktische klinische vaardigheden (PKV) bestaat uit drie onderdelen: PKV-MT (medische technieken), PKV-MA (medische anamnese) en PKV-CA (communicatie en attitude). Het CA-onderwijs begint in Bachelor 1, PKV-MT en PKV-MA starten in Bachelor 2. In Bachelor 3 worden CA, MA en MT ook gecombineerd in de lessen APC (Arts Patiënt Contact). Daarnaast leert de student acute hulp te verlenen.

column1: The Bachelor Graduation Project offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research design, and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Arts and Culture Studies. After successful completion of the Bachelor Graduation Project, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and provide an adequate report on their research and findings.
During the Bachelor’s Graduation Project, students are expected to perform the following activities independently, but under the supervision of a lecturer:
•             Demarcate and study a particular subject in the field of Arts and Culture Studies;
•             Formulate a relevant and appropriate definition of a problem and research question(s) that derive from this;

column2: • Formulate a relevant and appropriate research design;
• Formulate an appropriate method of analysis with an adequate reporting and analysis of the results;

• Write a thesis that adequately describes the entire research process, from formulating research problems, creating a theoretical framework, describing the chosen methodology and methods, and provides clear arguments for analyses, results, and conclusions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>During the Bachelor Graduation Project, students demonstrate and combine the knowledge and skills acquired during the three-year BA program, or one-year premaster program, in the form of a bachelor thesis. Students learn how to formulate and design an appropriate research study in the field of Arts and Culture Studies.</body>

column1: The goal of this extra-curriculair program is to extend economic knowledge and to increase academic skills. Participating students follow intense and interactive guest lectures by experts in the fields of science, business and politics concerning various current economic issues. They also write and present academic papers, participate in cultural activities and work on their personal development within the setting of the Honours Class.

column1: The final product of the Bachelor Project is the bachelor thesis: an individual research report of maximum 8,500 words (10,000 including cover page, table of contents and appendices). Students choose a thesis topic from one of the themes offered. The themes correspond to the content of learning paths in the Public Administration programme.

An introductory session will be held in period 6. During this session, the structure of the Bachelor Project will be explained, and the themes will be presented. The tutorials and supervision for the Bachelor Project will subsequently start in period 7. At least 1 tutorial group consisting of approximately 8 students will be established for each theme and these groups will be supervised by lecturers affiliated with a particular theme. Supervision usually takes place in (smaller) thesis groups consisting of around 4 students. In total, eight sessions have been planned (not including the introductory session).

Admission to the Bachelor Project course is only possible after the student has fully completed the Bachelor 2 (see article 4.2. of the Education and Examination Regulations). Students who do not meet the admission requirements, but still wish to take the Bachelor Project course, will have to submit a request to the Examination Board asking for permission to take this course (see Canvas, Contact: request form Examination Board). It is recommended that students submit this request before period 7 commences. The Public Administration bachelor programme (and therefore the Bachelor Project) must be successfully completed in full in order to gain admission to a master programme. Consult the Education and Examination Regulations (EER) for supplementary admission criteria for Public Administration master programmes.

• The student is able to clearly report the research results in accordance with academic standards in a format that is accessible and understandable for academics and/or policy-makers.
• Based on a concrete scientific research project, the student is able to form an opinion and formulate recommendations.

column1: The bachelor’s thesis is an important assessment in the bachelor’s program because it tests the student’s ability to report about their own small-scale historical research. The bachelor’s thesis follows on the bachelor thesis class of a specific focus area. The bachelor thesis is considered as an independent course within the bachelor’s program. Students have to write their own thesis individually, although they can consult their supervisor by appointment. The different focus areas of
The bachelor’s thesis is an elaboration of the final paper of the bachelor thesis class. This implies that the students are asked to:

column2: • Expand their secondary and primary sources (e.g. longer period, more samples, broader geographical reach and/or a comparative approach).

column1: The student has to process the remarks of the teacher of the bachelor thesis class in the bachelor’s thesis. Students can find more information on the assessment criteria of bachelor’s thesis on MyEUR. Deadlines
For students following the Bachelor Thesis Class in term 2; the thesis should be written in term 3.
Theses that are submitted after the deadline will not be marked and will not get a re-sit opportunity.

The student is able to set up a small-scale research project under supervision. The students are able to formulate an elaborate research question which is the starting-point for their bachelor thesis. They can find and critically interpret different types of primary sources and engage with relevant secondary literature to answer this research question and they also are able to apply theoretical and methodological concepts in their research. Finally, the students are able to write an academic report about their small-scale research.</body>

column1: Students complete their Bachelor's programme by writing a Bachelor's thesis. Although the BA thesis is completed individually, students receive guidance while working on the thesis by means of a weekly thesis class, which starts in term 3 and continues into term 4. The classes are arranged around themes in accordance with the focus areas of IBCoM. In consultation with the lecturer, students develop a research question that is related to the wider theme of their thesis class.

The BA Thesis Class starts with a discussion of potential research subjects and addressing background literature as well as relevant research methods. The main part of the course concerns conducting the actual research. Students are invited to submit questions and to talk about the progress and results of their research.

The BA thesis is a reflection of the knowledge and research skills obtained in the field of Communication and Media. In addition, the BA thesis is designed to further train students' ability to develop, conduct and report on a theoretically informed, practically relevant, empirical study.</body>

DR Curtis', 'dr. L Green', 'dr. ME Hay', 'dr. SK Manickam', 'prof.dr. HAM Klemann']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first decades of the twenty-first century have been marked by a series of crisis: 9/11, the US-led invasions in the Middle East, the Arab Spring, the Financial Crisis of 2008, the rise populist politics in the West, and the geopolitical and economic tensions arising as a result of the resurgence of Russia and China. Are these crises and conflicts inherent to the international and economic order that has been established post-WWII, or are we living through a rare watershed moment in history that marks the breakdown of the old order in favour of a reconstructed and reconfigured international and economic order?
This course aims to offer students the opportunity to understanding the global turmoil of the twenty-first century through exploring the long twentieth century.

Students are encouraged to pursue their research interests independently to identify a topic that is feasible in terms of source availability and historiographical contribution, but advice and assistance is offered to guide this process.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course serves to prepare students for researching and writing up the BA thesis. By the end of this course, students are able to formulate a research question, to develop a research methodology, to embed their research question in relevant historiographical debates, and, finally, to locate and analyse critically primary source material to postulate an academically rigorous answer to their research question.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102857,2021,Bachelor Thesis Class Friendcraft: forging bonds of friendship in Politics and International Relations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. Y van Hoef'],,"Inhoud
‘But when you talk about friendly relations in politics, it's not the friendship of schoolmates, of the Arbat’

Historians study both individual relationships, such as the famous friendship between Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, but also positive bonds between nations like the Special Relationship and Franco-German Cooperation. Others consider the role of networks and social movements, and friendships within civil society, even studying friendship within terrorist organizations. Many studies focus on how the meaning of friendship itself has changed through history, for instance how ancient friendship treaties that traditionally represented equality became treaties of subjugation, like those between the young US Republic and the native American nations. Other studies focus on processes of reconciliation, between France and Germany, but also between the latter and Israel.

In this BTC, the weekly class is divided in two parts. In the first part, we discuss in-depth 2-3 important contemporary articles by leading scholars on the subject, while in the second part we focus on a practical aspect of the thesis. In that way, you will gain both an in-depth understanding of the current historiography and of the most modern relevant methods of performing research for your own thesis subject.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this BTC you will be:

column2: Skilled in the most modern methods of performing research in the humanities and social sciences
Intimately familiar with the leading contemporary works on friendship and emotions in politics and international relations
Intimately familiar with the leading works and authors in your own thesis topic
Able to produce a convincing and professional research proposal
Perfectly primed for writing your BA thesis on a related topic

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100063,2021,Bachelor Thesis Class Globalization, resistance and the religious/cultural (re-)construction of group boundaries",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. CLA Willemse', 'dr. DR Curtis', 'dr. L Green', 'J Beocanin']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Globalization refers to an acceleration of the speed of change in and the increasing interconnectedness of different parts of the world. The colonial and postcolonial era are marked by these rapid transformation processes, also referred to as ‘modernization’, due to expanding trading networks, transnational labour migration, religious networks, ideological movements etc. This thesis class focusses on a ‘bottom-up’ perspective of the ways in which diverse groups of people who have moved from rural to urban areas or even transnationally have used religion and/or culture in order to resist these transformation processes. This resistance can be overt or covert, by use of violence or peaceful, by facing or by withdrawing from ‘modern’ society. Whether resistant or accommodating, pointing out a ‘significant other’ is part of the (re-)construction of boundaries. The question that is central to all of these coping strategies is how are discourses of religious/cultural ‘authenticity’ intersected with other identifications such as gender, generation, ethnicity, location, race and class to redefine group membership.

Students can choose from a wide range of geographical, historical and socio-cultural groups and will  ‘map’ the ways these groups have used religious and/or cultural aspects in order to cope with globalization and modernization in the (post)colonial encounters with ‘others’. Examples are the Rastafari in the Caribbean and Africa, the Maori in New Zealand and the Candomble in Brazil. Religious groups such as the Falun Gong in Asia, and shamanistic cults in South Africa ; the vast growing Pentecostal Church in Africa, Asia and Latin America; or the rise of the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt and Sudan to political power. But also resistance led by charismatic leaders like Ahmadu Bamba of the Mouride Brotherhood in Senegal, Muhammad al-Mahdi in Sudan or Ahmed Deedat in South Africa; or the resistance of the Nama led by Hendrik Witbooi in Namibie or against colonial powers. Also less visible millennial movements and cargo cults in Micronesia, New Guinee and West Africa and the importance of ethnic-nationalism and the ( re-)invention of ethnic dress, food, rituals and music among migrant communities in Europe and the USA can be studied. The primary sources are ample, like newspaper articles, speeches of charismatic leaders, colonial reports, paintings and pictures, items of material culture, videos, debates on the correct way of (changing) rituals on websites, interviews etc.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>When thinking about maritime history, one will in the first place think of ships and the history of the development of ships. But maritime history also is the history of overseas contacts, struggle between maritime powers over trade routes and colonies, the development of ports and the social conflicts there, the first contacts of Europeans with people from other continents and the position of sailors and their families. It therefore is about trade an trade conflicts, war and colonial expansion, the ideas of Europeans on people from Africa or Asia, on the position of these people when they came in a European port and racial conflicts in ports as shipowners preferred black people over whites as the former were less paid. On the position of women that had to raise a family without a husband as he lived on a ship or even died on sea, and as a consequence the quantitative dominance of women in sailor communities. Of course, it also is about sailing and trade and warfare on sea. In this course we will concentrate on a few aspects:

column2: • Economic aspects: The sea as a link between markets and the enormous growth of transport and ports in the last two centuries
• Political aspects: Ideas about controlling the sea as a method of controlling the world and the competition between the navies of major powers
• Warfare: Why were wars fought on sea, and why not?
• Cultural conflicts and racism: Ports as places where people from diverse background and colour met and the (race) conflicts that resulted from it.
• Women and the sea: how did women cope with the problem that they had to raise their families alone when the men were at sea.

column1: Note: the maximum number of participants is 12.</body>

column1: The interventions, rationales and rhetoric of modern medicine and health are ubiquitous in our contemporary lives. Yet this particular present was very recent in its making. This course looks at the rise of ""medicine"" and ""health"" as objects of inquiry and government intervention, particularly in the colonial and imperial realms. Far from being neutral realms of knowledge, the formation of medicine and ideas of health are intertwined with social, economic and political stratification which are the result of local and global conditions with historical antecedents, often involving regimes of coercion and violence such as imperialism and the concomitants of modernization and globalization. Which groups were included or excluded from medical and health considerations in the past and why? How has imperialism in its various forms affected the cultures of medicine and health in diverse locations?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Twentieth Century International Business in Times of Political and Economic Crisis

The Twentieth Century was marked by a series of crises that changed the world. The First and   Second World War not only caused suffering and death on a scale hitherto unknown, they also profoundly changed the world in both a political and economic sense. The interwar period was marked by slow economic recovery, rising protectionism and a number of severe economic crises, both regional and worldwide. The Cold War prevented a return to the level of globalization that had been destroyed with the outbreak of the First World War. It was only with the end of the Cold War   that globalization would attain the levels it had at the turn of the century. Yet the nature of this late- twentieth century globalization - while very familiar in many aspects - was also very different from what had gone on before. The course allows students considerable leeway in examining how these events impacted international business both on the short and longer term, and particularly the economic and political consequences of both World Wars, the Great Depression, the Cold War, and Decolonization.
Note: the maximum number of participants is 12</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>With the onset of the Industrial Revolution, there also started a process of economic integration. This happens both on a large scale – e.g. globalization processes culminating in the first wave of globalization in the second half of the nineteenth century – and on a smaller scale – e.g. the Dutch and German economies, and what is commonly known as the transnational Rhine economy. Obviously, these are complex and broad subjects, so for your BA-thesis in this theme you should think about a subject that touches on an aspect of this. Below are just a few aspects that have sparked an extensive literature. Use one of these – or another aspect – as a starting point to come up with your own BA-thesis sized research subject:

column2: • Finance: trade needs to be financed, and international investments are a major part of economic globalization. The Dutch were major investors in nineteenth century American railways. Those same railways were part of the First Transport Revolution that caused an agricultural crisis in Europe and a shift in Dutch agriculture towards knowledge-, labor-, and capital-intensive types of agriculture. Money is important in other ways as well: both the reparations payments that France had to pay Germany after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 and the reparations Germany had to pay the Allies after WW1 caused lasting resentment.
• Trade: trade is the most obvious way in which economies are interwoven. But how does that evolve, and why? How is that transported, what patterns emerge, how do they change, and why?

• International relations theory: the relationship between conflict and economic integration is a much-debated issue in international relations theory. Some argue that is brings peace, because war would interrupt trade, making it too costly. Others argue that the effects are the opposite: when economies become interdependent, this makes a country vulnerable. This could become a reason for the more powerful of the two countries to annex the less powerful country. You could use IR theory to study how disputes regarding trade or border issues are resolved, but there are many other possibilities.

column1: These are but a few examples of how economic integration can have unexpected consequences. I invite you to come up with subjects for your thesis that touch upon an aspect of this theme. Quantitative approaches are welcomed.</body>
At the end of this BTC you will be:

column2: • Skilled in the most modern methods of performing research in the humanities and social sciences
• Intimately familiar with the leading contemporary works on friendship and emotions in politics and international relations
• Intimately familiar with the leading works and authors in your own thesis topic
• Able to produce a convincing and professional research proposal
• Perfectly primed for writing your BA thesis on a related topic

column3: Bachelorscriptie bouwt voort op de vakken Leeronderzoek I en Leeronderzoek II  uit Bachelor 2. Het grootste verschil met beide leeronderzoeken is dat in het Bachelorscriptie individueel verslag wordt gedaan van het uitgevoerde onderzoek. Tijdens het uitvoeren van het onderzoek kunnen studenten echter wel deels gezamenlijk optrekken. Sterker nog, in veel gevallen, zoals bij het verzamelen van data, is dat zelfs expliciet de bedoeling, omdat anders het tijdsbestek van dit vak te kort kan zijn. Het onderzoek wordt – net zoals bij de leeronderzoeken – intensief begeleid door een docent. Wat bij de leeronderzoeken – en methodologische vakken – aan bod is gekomen wordt voor het uitvoeren van dat onderzoek echter wel als bekend verondersteld. Het staat studenten natuurlijk vrij om weer bij de hoorcolleges van die vakken aan te schuiven om deze voorkennis weer op te frissen.

Dit vak beoogt studenten te ondersteunen bij de uitvoering van het onderzoek waarmee zij de Bacheloropleiding afronden. Van dit onderzoek dient verslag te worden gedaan in een bachelorscriptie, dat de vorm heeft van een onderzoeksartikel. Het vak bestaat uit zes bijeenkomsten waarin de studenten met de docent die hen begeleidt de voortgang van het onderzoek bespreken. De studenten voeren dit onderzoek uit aan de hand van een onderzoeksthema aangereikt in de vakken Modernisering 3: Beleids- en organisatiesociologie, Cohesion 3: Deviance en Identity 2: Politics and Society.

column1: • De student leert een sociologisch- of beleidsrelevante probleemstelling te formuleren die hij/zij beantwoordt door het uitvoeren van een kleinschalig empirisch onderzoek.
• De student leert gebruik te maken van theorieën door daar hypothesen of kwalitatieve onderzoeksvragen van af te leiden.
• De student leert op een verantwoorde wijze concepten te operationaliseren.
• De student voert zelfstandig empirisch onderzoek uit op secundaire of zelf-verzamelde data, daarbij gebruikmakend van de relevante methoden en technieken voor sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek.
• De student leert de sociologisch-theoretische waarde van haar/zijn onderzoeksbevindingen, alsmede de beleidsrelevantie daarvan.
• De student leert onderzoeksresultaten helder en logisch te rapporteren.

Er zijn verscheidene werkcollegegroepen, elk rondom een bepaald bestuurskundig thema. Studenten kiezen binnen het thema van hun groep voor een specifieke probleemstelling. column1: <body>Het Bachelorproject vormt de afsluiting van de Bacheloropleiding. De kennis, inzichten en vaardigheden die in de opleiding zijn verworven, worden nu toegepast, geïntegreerd en verdiept door een bepaald onderwerp te onderzoeken. Na afloop van het Bachelorproject kan de student:

column2: • De student is in staat om bestuurskundige (sociaalwetenschappelijke) theorieën en concepten toe te passen en te gebruiken om inzicht te verwerven in een bestuurskundig/sociaal fenomeen.
• De student is in staat om een concreet bestuurskundig (sociaalwetenschappelijk) onderzoek te ontwerpen, uit te voeren en hierop te reflecteren.
• De student is in staat om op academisch niveau en op heldere wijze te rapporteren over onderzoeksresultaten in een vorm die voor academici en/of beleidsmakers toegankelijk is.
• De student kan op basis van een concreet wetenschappelijk onderzoeksproject een oordeel vormen en advies formuleren

column1: <body>De volgende ingangseisen gelden voor het Bachelorproject (conform artikel 4.2 van het OER):   1. Toelating tot de onderdelen van bachelor-2 en bachelor-3 kan uitsluitend plaatsvinden nadat de student een positief bindend studieadvies heeft ontvangen.  2. Toelating tot het vak ‘bachelor thesis’, ‘bachelorscriptie’, ‘bachelorwerkstuk’, en/of ‘bachelorproject’ kan uitsluitend plaatsvinden nadat de student bachelor-2 volledig heeft afgerond.   Studenten die niet aan de toelatingseisen voldoen, maar toch het Bachelorproject willen volgen, moeten hiertoe een verzoek indienen bij de Examencommissie. Aan te raden is om dit ruim vóór aanvang van het vak te doen. Voor specifieke vragen kan men zich wenden tot mevr. Nathanja Boers via het contactformulier van het Onderwijsbureau Bestuurskunde en Sociologie.  De bachelor opleiding (en dus het Bachelorproject) dient succesvol te zijn afgerond om toegelaten te kunnen worden tot de master opleiding. Voor aanvullende instroomeisen voor de master, zie het OER.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Bachelor thesis, students will work individually or in small groups on a literature review or an empirical study about a topic of their choice. Topics will be offered by the Psychology teaching staff. Teachers will supervise students during both the data/literature collection process, and the writing process. Furthermore, during the writing process, students will be supported through feedback from fellow students.

As a rule of thumb, literature reviews will include approximately 30 scientific references and will cover 20 pages (line space 1.5) or approximately 7000 words. This word count is excluding title page and references.
Empirical studies will include approximately 20 scientific references and will cover 13 pages (line space 1.5) or approximately 4500 words. This word count is excluding title page and references.

During the library practicals, students will learn to use advanced search techniques to find scientific information on a specific research question. In addition, students will learn to use reference software (RefWorks and Write-N-Cite)

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Being able to answer a research question based on empirical research or a scientific literature review is central to the Bachelor thesis. The Bachelor thesis is part of the academic writing trajectory, which is comprised of the following: year 1: Writing Skills I, year 2: Writing Skills II, year 3: Bachelor thesis, year 4: Master thesis. Within this trajectory, students first learn about basic writing skills (such as structuring paragraphs and creating links between paragraphs), after which they learn more advanced skills (such as sound argumentation based on scientific sources or data, as well as creating links between various sources). A second important skill used in academic writing is the giving and processing of feedback. Finally, a series of library practicals is featured in which students learn how they can systematically get an overview of scientific literature within a specific field of research.

column1: The Bachelor’s Thesis Class offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research question and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Arts and Culture Studies. After the BA Thesis Class, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and report on this research in their BA thesis.
As for the Bachelor’s Thesis, students are expected to perform the following activities independently under the supervision of a lecturer:
•             Demarcate and study a particular subject in the field of Arts and Culture Studies
•             Formulate a relevant and appropriate definition of the problem and research questions derived from this
•             Draw up a research structure outline, perform and document research
•             Write a thesis that meets academic requirements in terms of substance, composition, and language

column1: <body>This course aims at training and improving students’ academic writing skills and will result in an academic paper of 4,000 words (footnotes, bibliography and appendices not included). This course will guide students through the various stages of writing a larger academic paper, such as: finding and selecting relevant literature and sources; phrasing a research question; planning, drafting and revising the manuscript and using references. Attention will also be paid to research ethics and scholarly integrity. The tutorials will outline and introduce main issues of academic writing and will support the research and writing process. The final result of this course is a well-structured essay which answers a self-selected research question by means of a critical analysis of secondary literature. The paper is written in correct English or Dutch and uses correct references and citations.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In this course the emphasis falls on the following skills: 1) Finding and selecting relevant literature and sources; phrasing a research question; planning, drafting and revising the manuscript and using references. 2) Writing a well-structured and well written paper based on a self-proposed analytical research question, based on well-founded and clearly reasoned arguments, supplied with correct footnotes and bibliography, written in correct Dutch or English.</body>
