column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course in ‘Business Analysis and Valuation’ you will learn the basic concepts of financial statement analysis, enabling you to understand how financial reports are used by investors and to take a fundamental approach to equity (and debt) valuation.

The course has a practical emphasis. We adopt the view of an active investor and apply methods of fundamental analysis in a series of real-life exercises, cases, and assignments involving listed companies. We examine various valuation methods—residual earnings, abnormal earnings growth, and discounted cash flow approaches to valuation, among others—and ask which one will give us an edge. We do all this under the strict discipline of a fundamentalist: separate what you know from speculation and anchor in what you know from analysing financial statement information.

Just as importantly, we learn how to handle accounting and financial reports in valuation. We see that valuation is really a matter of accounting for value. The course combines accounting principles and investment principles to answer the question: How do I account for value so that I can challenge stock prices with some confidence?

As members of RSM, we aim to be a force for positive change in the world, using as guidance the framework set out by the UN Sustainability Development Goals (SDGs) to address the most urgent social, economic, and environmental challenges. Business analysis and valuation can play a leading role in allocating resources to sustainable companies and, thereby, accelerate the transition to a sustainable economy. We will discuss how environmental, societal, and governance (ESG) performance affects firm value. For example, a strategy analysis (Learning Goal (LG) 2) includes the assessment of a firm’s innovation (SDG 9) and responsible production (SDG 12), which can significantly affect a firm’s expected profitability and growth, two key drivers of future performance and value. Credit agencies may increasingly lower their assessments of firms’ creditworthiness (LG 7) for environmental liabilities expected to result from pollution (SDG 6). Similarly, when pricing risk for valuation purposes, environmental damages significantly affect a firm’s cost of capital (LG 8).

The course discusses techniques that are commonly used in an equity research department of a bank, independent research firm, or equity hedge fund. However, the material covered in the course is just as relevant to the corporate business analyst or financial consultant, for private equity analysis, for evaluating acquisitions, restructurings and other investments, and for calculating the value generated by strategic decisions. Thus, the course is of interest to those contemplating careers in investment banking, security analysis, accounting, consulting, and corporate finance.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: On completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand the environment in which financial reporting by companies takes place;
• Analyse business strategies to understand the value that they add;
• Determine the quality of the accounting in financial reports and undo accounting distortions;
• Analyse a firm’s operating and investment performance through ratio and cash flow analysis;
• Understand theories on capital structure and dividend choice;
• Analyse a firm’s financing and dividend decisions;
• Understand the primary determinants of the cost of capital;
• Forecast future financial statements, determine the cost of capital, and apply fundamentals-based valuation techniques;

• Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular valuation case, and present and defend the joint findings and conclusions in a report.Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular valuation case, and present and defend the joint findings and conclusions in a report.

column1: The business analytics course is about statistical and machine learning methods and techniques and the application of these techniques in research situations. The course has a theoretical part, which explains the background of these methods and techniques, and an applied part, which builds the skills for using them in research situations. The lectures address the theoretical background of measurement and analysis techniques, and give examples of survey development and the application of data processing techniques. The weekly assignments train the programming skills to apply the techniques in practice. The group assignments embeds these techniques in  a relatively unstructured task to address a self-selected topic in the sustainability domain, specifically the sharing economy.  The course contributes to independent evaluation and application of quantitative empirical research.
Specifically, the following topics will be covered:

column2: • General methodological topics related with causal inference, hypothesis formulation, conceptual frameworks, and measurement scales
• Classification methods using logistic regression, decision trees, random forests,  gradient boosting, and naive Bayes
• Clustering by means of k-means and hierarchical methods
• Assessing the performance of estimated models, both regression models and classification techniques
• Elementary text mining and sentiment analysis, using Tweets, news articles, and possibly other online sources
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of this course is to learn quantitative empirical methods and techniques commonly used in practice, and to train the programming skills to apply these methods in research practice. More specifically, the learning objectives of this course are:

column2: •  Design and execute empirical research following the common stages of the empirical cycle, viz., problem definition, formulation of hypotheses, (online) data collection, preparing data for analysis, analyze and report
• Understand and apply the common statistical and analytics methods used in business, both in terms of assumptions and operation

• Ability to apply statistics and analytics in programming, involving data processing, selection and application of relevant analytical functions, collect and present the outcomes of analyses; solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio
• Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders
• Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, team work and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

column1: The Business Analytics Workshop course involves completing a data analytics project for a company or organization. Together with the partner organization, teams of students formulate research questions, obtain and analyze data, and interpret and present their results.

Students are guided through the project by faculty supervisors. Guidance provided to students focuses on two domains: general skills and knowledge, and specific feedback on the project they conduct. Guidance related to general knowledge and skills focuses on project management, choice and application of research methods, and visual and oral presentation of results. In addition, students receive continuous feedback on their project progress from their peers as well as from supervisors.

Before the start of the course, students must indicate their preference for one of three tracks: (1) marketing, (2) supply chain management & business information management, or (3) accounting & finance. Based on these preferences, faculty supervisors form teams and allocate the teams to projects ahead of the course start.

column3: • Quality of feedback provided to other student teams

column1: The course has 11 learning objectives across two domains.

column2: Formulate appropriate research questions given stakeholders' interests and practical limitations
Define data needs and obtain necessary data from relevant stakeholders
Combine appropriate analytical methods with core models of marketing, finance, operations, information systems, or accounting to analyze data
Interpret findings and formulate implications of results
Assess and provide constructive feedback on data analytics projects

column1: B. Learning complementary skills needed in data analytics projects:

column2: Develop and update a project plan and manage a project in a diverse team
Develop and follow a structured approach towards the solution of an ill-defined business problem
Communicate with relevant stakeholders to set up and manage a data analytics project
Report project progress and results to diverse audiences
Reflect on ethical aspects of a project and the own role in the project

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In Business Architecture & Transformation we aim to explain the role of digital and leadership capabilities within organizations and how to assess these capabilities. We will present you with the concept of operating models and demonstrate on real life examples which operating model fits which kind of company. We will explain the difference between digital operations and digital strategy. Further, we will look into how investments in IT can be assessed.   We will point out the importance of IT governance to achieve strategic alignment between IT and business. Finally, we will talk about what really makes a true management leader in IT.

While you have looked into how to strategically use information and how to design business applications in the first block of your core courses we try to give you a perspective on how you can manage IT projects on a higher level. We look into the business and management perspective of transformation processes and how strategic decisions on a CIO-level should be made.
This course is a combination of lectures, guest lecturers, in class case analysis, and discussions.

Specific course guidelines will be made available via Canvas prior to the beginning of the course and need to be read and understood by each participant. Further, the textbook for the course needs to be purchased prior to the start of the course.
The assessment of the course can be divided into 2 main parts: (1) Individual: Final Exam, and (2) Group Assignments.

Group assignments focus on transformation projects for which students will face challenges in which they need to practically apply the tools and methods that they have theoretically studied for the course. Through specific grading criteria and feedback we help students to be able to recap their work and learn from its positive as well as negative aspects.

In the final exam students are assessed based on their understanding of the complete course both from a theoretical as well as practical perspective. The exam covers all themes presented in the lectures and guest lectures as well as the complete reading material.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Business Architecture & Transformation focuses on managing activities of information resources within firms that are crucial for firm success. Although, understanding information technologies and their role in transforming businesses is important this offers only one part of the picture. Success of firms depends on both digital and leadership capabilities.
At the end of Business Architecture & Transformation a student is able to:

column2: • Evaluate the Digital and Leadership Capabilities within an organization
• Create a Digital Strategy for an organization
• Apply the main concepts of a Digital Transformation to an organizational context
• Determine the appropriate Digital Governance Structure for an organization
• Analyze the IT Funding Guidelines of an organization

column1: The course is divided into weekly themes containing several topics per theme.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The financial crisis of 2008 led to public discussion about a possible lack of moral conduct in the corporate world. Ethics and compliance became terms often used in the financial sector. The pressure for financial organizations to comply with laws and regulations and implement compliance measures to live up to ethical standards is since then ever-increasing. Compliance measures and ‘ethics & compliance’ departments are now commonplace within the financial sector. This course will provide students with academic knowledge on what business ethics means in practice for financial organizations. It will help students to better understand crucial ethics and compliance concepts and how their own ethical behavior is sometimes influenced by external factors. It is important for the future finance professional to be aware of this as working in the financial sector will mean that they will get in contact with these concepts.
Workshop 1: Ethics and misconduct in the Financial Sector: Welcome to the Dark Side?

We discuss what is meant with the terms “ethics” and “compliance” in the context of a business organization. In the lecture we take a behavioral (as opposed to a philosophical) approach in order to understand what factors influence human behavior concerning ethics & compliance. What influences people towards morally good or bad decisions? We discuss different examples of misconduct from the financial sector.

We will further discuss several examples of ethical issues and compliance violations from the financial sector in an interactive way. We have studied academic articles on behavioural concepts, and we will use these to apply and deepen our knowledge gained in the first lecture.
Workshop 3: Compliance Management: Rules to protect us from the Dark Side?
We will discuss several examples on how to manage ethical behavior. We will discuss the following questions:
1.    How can we make employees comply with laws, regulations and guidelines?
2.    What are the pitfalls of all these rules and controls?
3.    How does an organization make the best use of compliance instruments like a Code of Conduct and a whistleblowing procedure?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After having followed this course students are able to understand important concepts of ethical behavior and how this knowledge can be used for managing compliance in an organization. After following this course students are better equipped to recognize the ethical pitfalls of dilemma situations within a working environment.</body>

column1: prof. dr. W.E.H. Dullaert (VU), prof. dr. W. Stam (VU), prof. dr. ir. B.G.C. Dellaert (EUR), prof. dr. S.N. Khapova (VU), prof. dr. A. Menkveld (VU), prof. dr. M.H. Huysman (VU).

The course provides a synopsis of the types of decisions each business field faces, highlighting the most relevant topics and problems per field, as well as how data science can help to address these business problems. The broad objective of this course is to present the students with a business framework that will allow them to see how future courses relate to each other. It is not designed to answer all business questions, as the business world is much too complex to be “covered” in a single course. Instead, this course is designed to generate more questions than can be answered. The answers to those questions will come later as students proceed through the business data science curriculum all the way to their research master thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the basic principles of business, including the types of decisions that each business discipline faces.
2. Explain how the various functional areas of a business (such as marketing, organization, logistic, finance) contribute to the formulation of common business decisions.
3. Identify relevant business problems per research discipline.
4. Understand how data science can be used to address these business problems.

5. Have an understanding of business that allows them to broadly read and understand the current scientific literature in business and management, and follow scientific debates across these sciences.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Fashion has often been studied from a cultural or costume history perspective. This course aims to highlight other important aspects of fashion and focuses on the fashion industry. The main objective of this minor is to gain insight into the business historical dimensions of the fashion industry and the importance of fashion for the global and local economy. It delves into the history of fashion companies and intermediaries, the economic characteristics of the fashion products and its markets. Students will thus study past and recent developments in the fashion industry. They will gain a historical, business, economic perspective of the fashion industry through a mix of lectures, seminars, guest lecturers and field trips.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective is to look into the history of the fashion industry and the world behind the glamorous catwalks and shiny magazines. It aims to analyse fashion from a business history perspective, to look for similarities and differences with other industries. After completing the minor, students should have a wide-range knowledge and critical understanding of the historical, business, economic dimensions of fashion and of the particularities of fashion products, businesses, and intermediaries.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the past decades, advances in information technology (IT) have fundamentally altered essential aspects of our society, our economy, and our individual lives. The Internet and digital technologies in general have radically impacted our personal and professional routines and challenged our perception of physical and social boundaries, of distance and speed, of how we want to live, work, learn, communicate, compete, collaborate, and socialize. The verdict is still out on whether digital technologies isolate us or brings us closer together, whether they provide a voice to the marginalized or help to suppress them, whether they bring about prosperity for the many or only for the few. Business plays a critical role in answering these questions since it is both, fundamentally affected by digital change and a main driver of the same. Traditional industries often struggle to adapt to this changing environment, with their business models being disrupted by new, agile competitors. Evidence can be found in the multitude of startups transforming a variety of sectors, such as energy, mobility, health, and finance. At the same time, the past decade has brought about a new set of platform-based business giants, including Google, Apple, Uber, Airbnb, and Amazon, which dominate the public discourse surrounding digitalization and raise new questions related to power and regulation in a digital world.

This course, Business Information Management acquaints students with the role of information technology in today’s economy and society. On the one hand, it provides a varied perspective on central discourses related to digitalization, such as the power of digital platforms, the boost digital technologies provide for the exchange of knowledge and ideas, but also the threat that a lack of regulation may pose. On the other hand, the course equips students with an understanding of digital technologies and with basic skills in algorithmic thinking, database management, and modelling required to thrive in today’s workplaces and academic programs. The course is offered by the Business Information Management group of RSM’s Department of Technology and Operations Management.

Pre-requisites: As Information Management cuts across all functions and disciplines it is assumed that participants have a basic grasp of all areas of business administration, including marketing, finance, operations, organizational behaviour, human resource management, and strategic management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Discuss the evolution of digital technologies and current technological trends.
• Evaluate the impact of established and emerging digital technologies on business, society, and your personal lives.
• Apply BPMN techniques to derive a business process model for a given business process.
• Organize a database model in a systematic way using Entity-Relationship-Modelling.
• Formulate SQL queries that manipulate databases to achieve a given outcome.
• Develop basic algorithms in R that achieve a given objective.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the past decades, advances in information technology (IT) have fundamentally altered essential aspects of our society, our economy, and our individual lives. The Internet and digital technologies in general have radically impacted our personal and professional routines and challenged our perception of physical and social boundaries, of distance and speed, of how we want to live, work, learn, communicate, compete, collaborate, and socialize. The verdict is still out on whether digital technologies isolate us or brings us closer together, whether they provide a voice to the marginalized or help to suppress them, whether they bring about prosperity for the many or only for the few. Business plays a critical role in answering these questions since it is both, fundamentally affected by digital change and a main driver of the same. Traditional industries often struggle to adapt to this changing environment, with their business models being disrupted by new, agile competitors. Evidence can be found in the multitude of startups transforming a variety of sectors, such as energy, mobility, health, and finance. At the same time, the past decade has brought about a new set of platform-based business giants, including Google, Apple, Uber, Airbnb, and Amazon, which dominate the public discourse surrounding digitalization and raise new questions related to power and regulation in a digital world.

This course, Business Information Management acquaints students with the role of information technology in today’s economy and society. On the one hand, it provides a varied perspective on central discourses related to digitalization, such as the power of digital platforms, the boost digital technologies provide for the exchange of knowledge and ideas, but also the threat that a lack of regulation may pose. On the other hand, the course equips students with an understanding of digital technologies and with basic skills in algorithmic thinking, database management, and modelling required to thrive in today’s workplaces and academic programs. The course is offered by the Business Information Management group of RSM’s Department of Technology and Operations Management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Discuss the evolution of digital technologies and current technological trends.
• Evaluate the impact of established and emerging digital technologies on business, society, and your personal lives.
• Apply BPMN techniques to derive a business process model for a given business process.
• Organize a database model in a systematic way using Entity-Relationship-Modelling.
• Formulate SQL queries that manipulate databases to achieve a given outcome.
• Develop basic algorithms in R that achieve a given objective.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Law and legal issues are deeply integrated in most facets of business. Our course introduces some of the core legal issues that managers commonly face. I have asked legal practitioners for input to guide the Core areas. In addition, there will be extra material available for those who want to explore more topics. To help structure the course, we will be using a textbook that takes a management, rather than a purely legal, approach to different topics. In addition, to emphasize the RSM mission of being a force for change, we will be emphasizing the ethical areas where law is less clear and managers must navigate challenges and face uncertainty.

The focus of the course will be on US and UK legal language and the common law system. This motivation is very practical: the vast majority of international contracts draw on these systems, English is most often the preferred language in international business dealings, and we need a common platform as a starting point to illustrate issues and develop awareness. In reality, some grounding basics really help managers identify legal issue, communicate with legal teams, and trouble shoot a range of business-and-legal issues (Bagley, 2008). We will highlight some major differences in systems and contracts (and other legal documents) throughout the topics.

The ultimate goal of the course is for you to begin to develop an awareness of legal issues and to add legal insights to your business acumen. A deeper understanding of legal issues in business can create advantages among managers and firms, leading to value creation and protection (Bagely, 2008). We know that legally astute managers with the ability to use legal language and communicate with a basic understanding of law are more effective negotiators, have stronger contracts, and are even able access more affordable financing. In addition, these managers are able to better manage alternatives to courts and legal conflict (Pinkham & Peng, 2017).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Identify legal issues relevant to the firm and international issue.
• Apply basic, English legal terminology in international contracts and other documents.
• Follow legal reasoning and how lawyers and fact finders may evaluate a case.

column1: Key business and management insights are vital to advance the conceptual and practical knowledge of the business world. In a knowledge-based and innovation-driven world, knowledge of the main business functional areas is an essential capability to gain a sustainable competitive advantage. Members of an organization, in any job and at any level, can make use of this knowledge to enhance work performance and make an impact in the process.

This course aims to provide foundational knowledge on key functional areas in business and management. The course is made of five modules, each of them two weeks long. The five components will cover basic functional areas and will be taught by leading scholars in each of these disciplines: (i) Organizational Behavior/Human Resource Management; (ii) Strategic Management; (iii) Finance; (iv) Supply Chain/Operations Management; and (v) Marketing Management. Overall, the minor answers this basic but foundational question:  What are the key insights and best practices in business management?

While strategies, investments, and operations are important for organisational success, an organization cannot excel if attention is not paid to its social capital – the human resources. This course provides an introduction to the study of human behavior in organizations. These behaviors are mainly explained in reference to psychological mechanisms, situational factors, individual differences, and group phenomena that influence the way people interact in the organisational context. We, therefore, focus on an individual level of analysis and on a team level of analysis.

Strategic management is a field of study concerned with developing understanding of why some firms are more successful than others. To advance students’ comprehension of how a company could potentially outperform its rivals, the present course focuses on the key theoretical ideas and concepts of strategic management and how to apply them in practice. We address both business-level and corporate-level strategy. Rather than viewing the firm as simply operating in a single business in a single geographic region, we also analyze the strategic options available to multi-divisional, multi-national firms. Moreover, because of the limitations of static analysis in the real world, the course underlines the dynamic nature of effective strategy formulation and implementation. This shifts the emphasis from generic strategies of cost leadership and differentiation based on industry analysis to strategies managers should develop for resource and knowledge building, entrepreneurship, leadership, innovation and learning. The course will focus on analyzing firm- specific unique resources and competences and their deployment for improving company performance. A key asset of the course is that theory is illustrated through real-life cases and examples so that students can not only learn, but also actively apply each of the core frameworks, discussed in the class, and master them.

This course is specifically designed for students with no background in accounting and finance. Regardless of how challenging, difficult, intimidating or scary the curriculum may sound to you at first, you will not only be able to keep up but, by the end of our course, have developed a strong economic intuition.

Together we will cover, elaborate on and explore the basic building blocks of (corporate) finance so that by the end of our course you will understand how financial managers make decisions on a day-to-day basis (for example decisions related to liquidity) , why and how firms invest in new projects (net present value and other investment decision criteria, capital structure theory) and how the value of a firm is increased (shareholder value maximization). Additionally, we will explore the abstract concept of risk and make it tangible and measurable by working through and applying the Capital Asset Pricing Model.

In order to achieve this, we will also cover significant parts of accounting, with a special emphasis on the core logic and mechanisms of balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement. This will enable us to engage in analysis of a firms most important “health”-parameters (i.e. financial statement analysis: liquidity, profitability, asset management efficiency, capital structure and market value).

Operations Management concerns all value adding processes directly related to the creation and realisation of tangible products and services. The essential point of the subject forms the fundamental idea that effective management of product or service producing organisations requires an integral approach. In this approach, a large number of disciplines play a role. In order to provide insight into what is really the role of different disciplines in various organisations, it is essential to have a closer look at the qualities of contemporary organisations that operate in a dynamic world. While operations management covers also more strategic decisions, in this course we will focus more on some decisions that have the greatest influence at tactical and operational levels. More specifically, we will look at the interaction between capacity and queueing, inventory management, scheduling, and the impact of layout decisions.

Marketing strategy is a complex business function that requires a balance of analytical and synthetic skills. This course introduces a series of frameworks and tools that can be used to a) solve general business problems and b) develop specific marketing strategies and programs.

The analytic part of the course moves from the general to the specific. The course is oriented around understanding the three Cs (customers, company, and competitors), developing a strategy for the chosen product/market(s), and translating this strategy into more specific plans through the elements of the marketing mix, the four Ps (product offering, pricing, promotion, and physical distribution).

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column5: <li>
Understand the key concepts of organizational behavior.
<li>
Analyze problems within organizations grounded in individual and/or team behavior.
<li>
Appreciate the complexity of managing employees and the importance of critical thinking to reduce biases for managerial decisions
<li>
Develop a foundational understanding of the principal theoretical frameworks and concepts linked to strategy formulation (both at the business- and corporate-levels) and strategy implementation.
<li>
Gain basic insights in how to apply the knowledge obtained through this course to diagnose the reasons behind good or bad organizational performance.
<li>
Understand how to formulate strategies that lead to value creation and how to develop strategic options to achieve sustained competitive advantage.
<li>
State and define the components of each of the financial statements (i.e. balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement), differentiate between them, and interpret them.
<li>

State and define the core categories of financial statement analysis (i.e. liquidity, profitability, asset management efficiency, capital structure and market value), select the appropriate metrics to measure them, execute the necessary calculations and interpret their results.
<li>
Describe the relevance of the time value of money in the context of valuating projects and firms and execute and interpret the associated calculations.
<li>
Define and describe absolute and relative risk measurements. Interpret and critique specific risk metrics and judge their impact on the cost of capital.
<li>
Explain the concept of diversification in the context of portfolio theory and differentiate between portfolios carrying different amounts of risk.
<li>
Understand the relations between different process characteristics and performance outcomes
<li>
Understand the characteristics of performance analysis, process design, and planning & scheduling
<li>
Solve quantitative problems in the context of performance analysis, process design, and planning & scheduling
<li>
Explain how marketing is a force for positive change by creating long-term value for customers, companies and society in general.
<li>
Develop a thorough understanding of the fundamental principles and practices in strategic marketing
<li>
Analyze a complex business case with a small group of colleagues
<li>
Apply analytical tools, including tools used in targeting, brand management and pricing

column1: Where theoretical knowledge serves as the foundation of your education as a manager, the ability to effectively and insightfully apply this knowledge is the key to success in most management jobs. Developing the ability to apply and translate theoretical knowledge to real world situations in which taking decisions and implementing them is central is of crucial importance for future managers and is the key aim of this course. Just like pilots learn to fly in a flight simulator, you and your team will learn through a simulation to run a company for the next 9 years (9 decision periods)! You start with a portfolio of existing brands and your ultimate goal is to maximize your stock price index 9 years later, through value creation for your consumers. During these 10 years, you and your team decide which segment(s) to focus on and with which brand(s); how to target each segment and which price to charge. You are responsible for the effective management of a portfolio of brands:  you can reposition existing brands, redevelop them or discontinue them, but you can also introduce and launch new brands and products. Moreover, you get the opportunity to conquer a completely new market and to create value through sustainable choices. Apart from having an in-depth understanding of the strategic aspects of marketing, it is of vital importance that you learn to interpret market research studies accurately. On top of that, just as in real life, your company doesn’t operate in a vacuum but in a competitive environment. Your team competes with five other firms (five other teams) for consumers’ attention within the ‘markstrat world’. Effective and timely anticipation of your competitors’ (re)actions is of crucial importance for successful management of your firm.

In this course, you will deepen your knowledge and understanding of marketing, strategy, finance, product development and leadership. Through active engagement in the simulation, you will develop the skills to translate this knowledge into actionable decisions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The student will have an in-depth understanding of concepts, theories and instruments important to marketing, and have the skills to apply these effectively in a way that creates value to the consumer. Therewith, the student obtains an understanding of how marketing can be a ‘force for positive change’ to the consumer.
• The student will have the knowledge and skills to appreciate and interpret different market research studies within a team.
• The student has insights in optimal resource allocation strategies and in quantifying returns on marketing investment within a team operating in a competitive landscape
• The student has the skills to anticipate forces and changes in the market and responses from key stakeholders while operating within a team.
• The student has developed leadership skills within the team to together with the skills to match external changes (in the market) with internal changes (in team structure and responsibilities)

• The student has obtained an understanding of different biases that interfere with optimal decision making of themselves and others within their role as a manager, and has the skills to fight these biases (e.g., overconfidence; attentional blindness)

column1: Het betreft een verdiepend vak, dat met name Europeesrechtelijk van aard is. Naast een aantal principes uit de Europese verdragen en richtlijnen komt de jurisprudentie over de BTW van het Hof van Justitie aan de orde, alsmede de ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de BTW en andere indirecte belastingen in Europa. Het vak vormt een aanvulling op het vak Omzetbelasting dat in de bachelorfase wordt aangeboden.

Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en vooraf in te leveren, om over de collegestof een mening te vormen. Iedere stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 1 A4 (450 woorden).

Tijdens de colleges gaan de docenten nader in op de stellingen en de daarover gevormde meningen van de studenten. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Beter en verdiepend inzicht verwerven in het Europese BTW-systeem in het bijzonder met betrekking tot specifieke en verdiepende deelonderwerpen.
• Het kritisch vermogen ontwikkelen om – zeker bij de deelproblemen – bij grensoverschrijdende transacties zelfstandig de fiscale belemmeringen op te sporen en op te lossen.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om dwarsverbanden te leggen en zelf met een deelonderwerp aan de slag te gaan, bijvoorbeeld voor het schrijven van een masterscriptie.

column1: Het kenmerkende karakter van het vak is dat het een verdiepend vak is. Dat betekent dat een aantal onderdelen die ook in de algemene vakken internationaal belastingrecht en Europees belastingrecht zijn behandeld, hier op een diepgaander niveau aan de orde komen. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een aantal specifieke deelterreinen van het internationaal en Europees belastingrecht.
Thema's die de revue passeren zijn onder andere:

Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en daarover hun mening te vormen. Elke stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 300 woorden. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer.

column1: Tijdens het vak Capita Aansprakelijkheidsrecht vergaart u kennis van diverse onderwerpen[1] op het gebied van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht. Bij dit vak wordt voornamelijk gebruik gemaakt van gastdocenten; specialisten op het gebied van de te behandelen onderwerpen. Naast de colleges, waarin een actieve werkvorm centraal staat, zijn er ook masterclasses. Tijdens deze masterclasses bezoekt u steeds een organisatie (advocatuur/verzekeringsbranche) waar een van de onderwerpen uit het vak wordt uitgediept waardoor direct de uitwerking daarvan in de praktijk zichtbaar is.

[1] De belangrijkste capita zijn structuur van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht, verjarings- en vervaltermijnen, beroepsaansprakelijkheid, werkgeversaansprakelijkheid, verkeersaansprakelijkheid, productaansprakelijkheid en overheidsaansprakelijkheid.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren en uiteen zetten.
• U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht toepassen op een feitencomplex.
• U kunt ten aanzien van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht een kritische houding aannemen, een standpunt innemen en in discussie gaan.
• U kunt op het gebied van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht ontwikkelingen signaleren, analyseren en (actualiteiten) bijhouden.
• U kunt verschillende leerstukken op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren, vergelijken, verbanden leggen en bepalen welke op een casus toegepast kunnen worden.
• U kunt de opgedane kennis van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht omzetten in praktische kennis en u kunt daarbij de trends en ontwikkelingen signaleren.

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder volgt een korte beschrijving van de Capita Selecta Transfer Pricing:

Tijdens de colleges staat het Transfer Pricing vakgebied centraal. Zo zullen wij tijdens de colleges uitgebreid stil staan bij de internationaalrechtelijke aspecten van Transfer Pricing, alsmede de Nederlandse implementatie van de Transfer Pricing regels, inclusief bijbehorende jurisprudentie. De Transfer Pricing discipline is volop in beweging. Tijdens de colleges zullen daarom ook de recente ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de Transfer Pricing aan bod komen.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken. Voor een nadere omschrijving wordt verwezen naar de brochures die per Capita Selecta beschikbaar zijn op Canvas.

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Caribisch fiscaal recht:

Tijdens de colleges wordt ingegaan op het fiscale stelsel van de BES eilanden (Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba) en ACS (Aruba, Curaçao en Sint Maarten). Aan de orde komen de staatkundige vernieuwing van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden, de directe en indirecte belastingen, formeel belastingrecht, belastingrechtspraak in het Caribisch gebied, tax incentives (tax holiday, e-zone), internationale aspecten (verdragen, BRN, BRK, verhouding met EU), misbruik van offshore vennootschappen (Panama leaks, 'Ultimate Beneficial Owner'), tax haven en ethiek. Daarnaast wordt een uitstap gemaakt naar het fiscale stelsel van Suriname.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de Caput Formeel Belastingrecht:

Tijdens de colleges worden relevante formeelrechtelijke onderwerpen belicht vanuit de praktijk, waarbij in de in de loop van de studie de behandelde onderdelen geïntegreerd worden bestudeerd. Aan de orde zullen onder meer komen de uitoefening van controlebevoegdheden door de inspecteur, fiscale handhaving, fiscaal procesrecht, invordering (incl. aansprakelijkstelling), internationale gegevensuitwisseling en de Nationale ombudsman.</body>

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in zes specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Van eenmanszaak tot internationaal concern:

De cyclus van 16 colleges wordt begonnen met verschillende aspecten die van belang zijn voor familievennootschappen. Daarbij gaat het om zowel civielrechtelijke als fiscaalrechtelijke aspecten. Onderwerpen die daarbij aan de orde komen zijn: ondernemingsfaciliteiten, bedrijfsopvolging in de inkomstenbelasting en vennootschapsbelasting, de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteit voor de schenk- en erfbelasting, het creëren van holdingstructuren, horizontaal toezicht en tax assurance, ethiek en renteaftrekbeperkingen.

Met betrekking tot het internationale deel van deze capita zullen de volgende onderwerpen behandeld worden: transfer pricing, classificatie van hybride entiteiten, doorstromers, immigratie en emigratie aanmerkelijkbelanghouder en vennootschap, verdragsonderhandelingen, BEPS/ATAD en belastingheffing in de digitale economie en fiscale aspecten van grensoverschrijdende werknemers en hybride entiteiten. De focus bij deze onderwerpen ligt op het internationale concern.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het verzekeringsrecht staat niet op zichzelf. Er wordt altijd ""iets"" verzekerd en dat ""iets"" kan met vele juridische deelgebieden verweven zijn. Verzekering vervult in onze moderne samenleving met alle daaraan verbonden kansen en risico's ook een onmisbare rol in het veiligstellen van de sociale zekerheid voor het individu. Dat maakt het verzekeringsrecht tot een boeiend onderdeel van het recht. Het betekent ook dat kennis van het verzekeringsrecht niet alleen onmisbaar is voor juristen die in de verzekeringsbranche zelf werkzaam (willen) zijn of bijvoorbeeld in de advocatuur de belangen van verzekeraars vertegenwoordigen. In feite loopt iedereen die in een juridische functie (rechterlijke macht, bedrijfsleven, overheid) werkzaam is, de kans met verzekeringsrechtelijke vraagstukken te worden geconfronteerd; zoals dat ook privé het geval is.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student kan de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht analyseren en uiteenzetten.
• De student kan de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht toepassen op een feitencomplex.
• De student kan ten aanzien van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht een kritische houding aannemen, een standpunt innemen en in discussie gaan.
• De student kan op het gebied van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht ontwikkelingen signaleren, analyseren en (actualiteiten) bijhouden.
• De student kan verschillende leerstukken op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht analyseren, vergelijken, verbanden leggen en bepalen welke op een casus toegepast kunnen worden.
• De student kan de opgedane kennis van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het verzekeringsrecht omzetten in praktische kennis en kan daarbij de trends en ontwikkelingen signaleren.

column1: This course is part of cluster 4. The Politics of Wealth: Inequality, Capitalism, Exploitation

This course covers state-of-the-art debates in political philosophy, including the debate on permissible commodification and the nature of markets, on contemporary justifications of property, on the feminist and the three-dimensional theory of power, on justice as fairness and its approach to economic inequality, on neo-republicanism, and on contemporary theories of exploitation.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To provide students with advanced knowledge of contemporary political philosophy. By the end of the course, students should have an understanding of state-of-the-art debates in political philosophy, the ability to think well about them, and the ability to assess relevant philosophical theories in terms of their cogency and explanatory scope.
Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100042,2021,Capitalism and Inequality,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. DR Curtis', 'R van Lent, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Crises such as the 2008/9 financial crash and COVID-19 have thrown a window on one of the world’s greatest issues – inequality. In this course, we place the emergence of capitalism and the growth of inequality in a long-term historical perspective. How did we get here? As with most of our pernicious contemporary challenges, much has its roots in developments going back far into the past. Over these 8 sessions, it’s our job to unravel them. Has history been one relentless march towards greater inequality, or have there been periods in which we have become more egalitarian? Is it possible to prevent inequality? Furthermore, what do we mean when say “inequality” – and how does that definition apply in specific historical contexts? Is something unequal if the society in question does not observe it to be unequal? A major aspect of this course is understanding some of the mechanisms that have led societies towards inegalitarian outcomes. What is the relationship between capitalism and inequality, or colonialism and inequality? What do we mean by “extractive societies”? How have hazards, shocks and disasters affected inequality, and vice-versa, how has inequality affected societies’ resilience, vulnerability and coping strategies in the face of hazards, shocks and disasters? And finally, how has economic inequality intersected with other issues regarding gender, race and sexuality, in order to forge new kinds of marginalization?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students can reflect upon the relative and fluid nature of the term “inequality” – recognizing it can mean something different depending on historical context.
• Students can plot the geographical and temporal dimensions of inequality over time for different parts of the world.
• Students can explain why certain historical societies have become more unequal in certain periods of time.
• Students can identify some of the consequences of economic inequality – especially in its interaction with other concepts such as resilience and vulnerability.

column1: Deze cursus is een verplicht onderdeel van het Career Skills programma. Alle bachelor-2 (en bachelor-3 studenten die deze cursus nog moeten doen) worden aan deze cursus toegevoegd. Om jouw inschrijving vervolgens definitief te maken dien je aanwezig te zijn bij de online kick-off. Als je daar niet bent wordt je automatisch uitgeschreven.
Het doel van Your Future Career is studenten vroeg in hun studietijd voor te bereiden op hun carrière.

Als je geeft om wat je doet, zal je met meer plezier werken, meer impact creëren, en succesvoller zijn. Het kan echter lastig zijn om erachter te komen wat jouw passie is, waar je jouw competenties en vaardigheden het beste in kan zetten, en wat voor professionele werkomgeving en -cultuur het beste bij je past. Het Career Skills programma biedt deze cursus aan om je de leiding te geven over je eigen carrière en je te ondersteunen in het kiezen voor en voorbereiden op je eerste stap in je carrière.

De online modules van Your Future Career helpen je om cruciale stappen te maken richting de stage of baan die het best bij jou past. Om de cursus succesvol af te sluiten dien je 50 punten te verdienen voor een gegeven deadline. Je kan zelf bepalen of je wil reflecteren op je interesses en motivaties, kennis op wil doen over de arbeidsmarkt, functies, organisaties en sectoren, of feedback van je medestudenten wilt ontvangen op je sollicitatie documenten.
Deze cursus begint in blok 3 en loopt tot eind blok 4. Je kunt niet halverwege de cursus starten.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Het op waarde schatten van je eigen professionele profiel in de grotere gemeenschap
- Pro-actief zijn met betrekking tot het voorbereiden op je carrière
- Analyseer je sterke en zwakke punten, personaliteit, waardes, en vaardigheden
- Identificeer verschillende carrièrepaden in de arbeidsmarkt
- Identificeer gaten in de voorbereiding op je carrière en creëer actiepunten om deze gaten te vullen
- Leer over het wervings- en selectieproces in verschillende sectoren
- Bepaal hoe jouw toekomstige carrière een kracht voor positieve verandering kan zijn
- Demonstreer geschreven en verbale communicatievaardigheden die nodig zijn in het sollicitatieproces</body>

Indien je in 2018-2019 of eerder met je bachelor begonnen bent, is Career Skills geen verplicht programma voor jou. column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Find a shortened description below. For more information, check out the Career Skills Hub Canvas page.

You can find the courses offered in the Career Skills programme in the study guide. To do so, open the study guide, choose ‘Erasmus School of Economics’, then ‘Overige onderwijs’ or ‘Miscellaneous’, then ‘Career Skills’.

Being a student is not only about getting that diploma. Your time at Erasmus School of Economics is an excellent opportunity to gain hands-on experience and develop the skills you’ll need to start a successful professional career. Make the most of your studies, strengthen your employability and make yourself sought after by recruiters.

The Career Skills programme aims to foster a better connection between the study at ESE and the labour market. After you have completed your first bachelor year you will experience that you need to make choices rapidly that define the rest of your (study) career: minor, major, electives, going abroad, a side job or other extracurricular activities… It is the wish of ESE to stimulate you to make informed choices regarding your studies and the start of your career. In addition, we want to support students in developing the skills necessary to succeed in a professional environment. That way, you will be well prepared to enter working life!
For whom is the Career Skills programme?

The Career Skills programme is obligatory for all ESE students who started their bachelor programme in academic year 2019-2020 or later. Students in Economics & Business Economics, Econometrics & Operations Research, and Fiscale Economie start with the Career Skills programme in the second year of their bachelor. BSc2 students start with the programme in the third year of their bachelor.

If you started your bachelor in 2018-2019 or earlier, Career Skills is not a mandatory programme for you. You can still follow one of the courses in this programme, for instance if you need one more credit to finish your bachelor. To register, send an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl.
What courses does the Career Skills programme offer?
In 2021/2022, you can choose between the following courses:

Initially, Model United Nations Rotterdam (MUNROT), organised by the EFR, would have been one of the courses on offer. Unfortunately, this event has been cancelled due to the pandemic. Furthermore, we hope to add one more course to the list this academic year.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102809,2021,Career Skills: AEclipse/ESE Debate Workshop Cycle,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['A Nelissen', 'JS Bol', 'T Hermann']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course will be divided into 3 main themes: Public Speaking, Argumentation, Real-world debating skills. During the course, students will be able to attend various lectures and workshops centered around these three themes, which build onto each other. Instructors in these lectures and workshops will consist of a variety of professors, professionals from companies and NGOs or experienced members of associations such as the Erasmus Debate Society. Throughout the course, students will be given assignments to prepare certain topics and arguments in order to be able to present them during the workshops. Hence, the lectures will serve as introductions to the topics and the related skills will be practiced during the corresponding workshops.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. Speech construction: Students learn the basic formatting principles to a speech and simple argument structures.
2. Public speaking skills: Students will learn how to better present themselves and increase their confidence for public speaking.
3. Argumentation skills: Students will be able to create solid and sound detailed arguments
4. Negotiation skills: Students will understand how a negotiation process works with basic negotiation concepts and principles

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is part of the Career Skills programme. Be aware that you can do a maximum of two courses per academic year.

If you started your bachelor in 2018-2019 or earlier, Career Skills is not a mandatory programme for you. You can still follow one of the courses in this programme, for instance if you need one more credit to finish your bachelor. To register, send an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl.

Note that, except for the course FEB13901(X) Your Future Career, all courses have limited places available. Students for whom Career Skills is mandatory have precedence when subscribing to Career Skills courses.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In every area of business, effective practitioners distinguish themselves from others through their ability to drive change and impact. This requires not only hard/technical skills but also the ability to thrive interpersonally. Effective practitioners distinguish themselves in several ways:
1. They leverage their technical expertise not only to solve problems but also to build credibility and lead their colleagues
4. They successfully influence the views, decisions, and actions of their entourage

These capabilities are especially important for professionals with quantitative backgrounds (economics, finance, accounting, etc…). Undoubtedly, mastering the hard skills in one’s area of expertise is a “must have.” But to become effective professionals who successfully influence decision-makers, quantitative experts must also be able to translate the results of their quantitative & analytical work into business insights, communicate these insights simply and powerfully, and formulate compelling perspectives and recommendations.
In this course, we will explore a few of the ‘social’ aspects that complement the technical dimension of quantitative sills.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: On completion of this course, students will learn:
1. How to design and structure effective business presentations
2. How to write quality slides that are easy to understand and convey powerful messages
3. How to orally deliver business presentations
4. How to prepare and conduct high impact meetings
5. How to identify important stakeholders, segment them and develop strategies to manage them
6. How to select and apply different influencing techniques for 1-1 interactions
7. How to reflect and assess one’s personal effectiveness at influencing

column1: Do you want to learn Dutch for your future career? Are you going to do an internship at a Dutch company? Or would you simply like to make yourself understood in the Netherlands? This Dutch language course will help you get there!

During the Dutch language course for beginners you will learn the basics of the Dutch language, with emphasis on reading, speaking, listening and writing skills in an everyday context. You do not need to pass an intake interview.
The course consist of seven meetings of two hours. Next to this, the self-study and preparation time amount to circa 14 hours.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99223,2021,Career Skills: English for Business Purposes,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['C de Back', 'KC Scully', 'ME Dijksma, BA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Before the start of the course you are required to submit, via Canvas, a motivation letter why you want to participate. This letter will be used in-class.
Effective business communication in English opens doors. Excellent communication skills in English are crucial for achieving international ambitions.

In this course you will work on your Business English writing skills, for example by writing polite, concise and correct business emails. You will also get the opportunity to practise your presentations skills in English by giving a persuasive and informative business presentation. You will learn more about conventions in Business English in this course. You will brush up your English grammar and you will be able to improve and expand your English vocabulary. By receiving individual feedback from your lecturer – who is an experienced language professional – you will be able to develop your business communication skills. You will also learn a great deal from working closely together with your fellow students.
This course consists of seven plenary sessions of two hours, on-campus or via Zoom as circumstances require. Next to this the self-study and preparation time amounts to circa 14 hours.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - You can write a coherent and well-structured English business text
- You can write correct English on the sentence level, including grammar, style, and vocabulary
- You will develop an efficient writing process
- You can give a good business presentation in English

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship, we are committed to developing people’s entrepreneurial skills because we believe these skills to be crucial for young people’s ability to successfully choose and shape their own career and life paths. Broader than the skills needed to establish and grow a company, an entrepreneurial mindset leads to more resilient individuals, that are better able to spot and strategically act upon opportunities.
During this course offered by Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship, you will work on developing the competencies needed to shape your career in an solution-oriented and impactful way.

The course consists of five modules, each highlighting a different ‘area’ of entrepreneurship. The three main pillars along which the modules are structured are the entrepreneurship process in a startup, in a startup/scaleup environment and in a corporate/public environment. You will practice with and reflect on this process throughout the course and apply it in the final module which will be a mini-innovation challenge. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Have developed an understanding of main entrepreneurial principles such as design thinking, lean startup and effectuation;
- Know how to apply the theory of effectuation and effectuation roadmap to concretize a vision or way to make impact that you identified during the course;
- Know how to apply entrepreneurial principles to identify and empathize with a target group for whom you want to realize your vision/impact;
- Are able to pitch yourself or your solution to a problem in front of different audiences including your (future) employer;
- Are able to ideate and come up with solutions to social/societal challenges pressure-cooker style.

column1: Social inequalities are found in various settings within society. In this course, you will learn about social inequality in the workplace, the biases we are prone to when it comes to social inequality and the importance of inclusive leadership to tackle inequality. Students will engage with the different leadership qualities and skills and will learn how to develop them and put them in practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Explain what social inequality entails, and in what way it exists in the workplace environment including the unconscious biases;
• Have an understanding of the different inclusive leadership qualities and how to apply them during their current life and in their future career;

column1: Additionally, personal learning goals for inclusive leadership will be created during the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this introduction to deliberate creativity students will learn the basic methods, principles and attitudes to  apply  creativity  in  their  daily  and  future  work,  using  the  integrated  creative  problem  solving  (iCPS)  approach. Integrated Creative Problem Solving is a three-stage approach, using deliberate creativity as a way to solve complex problems, in groups (Heijne and Van der Meer, 2019).

The strong connection with current and future practice, is established through the science-based and hands-on approach of the course. Through practicing repetitively the students will internalize the basic methods, principles and attitudes. Therefore, they can be easily applied now in their day-to-day live and will remain relevant in their academic and/or professional career.   </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The students will learn to apply methods, principles and attitudes of the three stages of the iCPS approach.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/102787,2021,Career Skills: Management of volunteer organisations,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. LCPM Meijs', 'PSM van Overbeeke, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Are you a member of a field hockey club, a student association, or a political party? In any of these cases, and many more, you were probably asked to give back at some point. For example, by refereeing a junior game, tending the bar for a few nights, or campaigning for your party. Did you realize that at that point you were volunteering? The Netherlands is a true volunteer country, almost 50% of individuals older than 15 donates their time at least once a year as a volunteer. On average, these volunteers spend about 4 hours a week at their volunteer-job. That is about 700.000 FTE! Could you imagine how much more a filed-hockey membership would cost if all these people would have to be paid? Free or low-cost services would have to be stopped or expensed in a different way and campaigning for political parties or foodbanks might be practically non-existent?

The value of volunteer hours, in essence unpaid labour, is exactly what we will focus on during this Career Skills Course. During interactive classes we will introduce you to the world of civil society, sometimes called the third sector (next to governments and for-profit businesses). We will explore the types of organizations in this sector and how these non-profit organizations are differently managed from their for-profit counterparts. An important part is volunteer management and evaluation, which will be the main topic of this course. More specifically, how can organizations value their volunteers? Is it only about the numbers, or is there more to it? And is value only created for the organization, or might there be other recipients as well?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course the student is able to:
1. Describe the functioning and complexity of non-profit, non-governmental and philanthropic organizations and the civil society (third sector)
2. Apply theoretical civil society concepts to real-life situations
3. Evaluate the value of volunteers for a non-profit organization of your choice
4. Analyze the differences between paid work and volunteering / for-profit and non-profit organizations
5. Advance a career in the third sector and in (impact) evaluation

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100827,2021,Career Skills: Managing complexity,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['C Heese, MSc', 'RJ Moelijker, MSc', 'SC Schaller, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course takes place twice in 2021/2022: in block 2 and 3.

The World Economic Forum predicts that 50% of jobs are to change in the next ten years – a trend that isn’t expected to slow down. Data abundance, automation, and global challenges are just a few of the driving factors. How can you prepare for your career when the jobs you will one day be working may not even exist yet?

One of the answers to this dilemma is learning transferable skills – skills that are useful and applicable across a variety of circumstances. Still, this requires a degree of prediction – which ones will still be applicable in the future, and, of these, which are most useful?

Overall, we can say that the world is becoming more complex – or rather, our operations are becoming more complex. Collaborations are bigger than ever before, our technological capabilities increase the horizons of what is possible, and data is abundant and (relatively) easily accessible. Your role as a knowledge worker is moving from being a knowledge holder to being a knowledge processer, where your impact comes from decomplexifying the world through effective processing, packaging, and communicating of ideas and knowledge. We are in the age of information and influence.

This course intends to prepare you for the future of work by teaching you how to effectively manage complexity. The course is structured to follow the core steps of processing information, as shown below.

• The first element is filtering input – it is about having a critical eye for information – identifying what is valuable, what is true, and what is missing. The first session will focus on critical thinking.
• Next comes processing the selected information – drawing conclusions and developing solutions. The second session will focus on problem solving.

• Finally, a solution is only useful when it can actually be implemented.  As we usually won’t be operating on our own (be it teammates, customers, decision makers, or any other stakeholder), communication or dissemination of your newly developed knowledge is key. The third and fourth sessions will focus on power & politics and rhetoric respectively.

The course ends with a final session where teams must present in order to demonstrate their ability to critically assess information, process this in an interesting manner, and effectively communicate their perspective/findings.

A central design principle of the course is interaction and application – sessions will consist chiefly of discussions and application. Theory is only involved to the extent of providing language for discussion. The primary goal of this programme is the development of your mental models, not simply expanding your knowledge base.
This course consists of six online (via Zoom) or in-person meetings, each of which is approximately 2 hours. The preparation time will be approximately 17 hours.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing this course successfully, the student will be able to:
• Critically evaluate the validity of different types and sources of information.
• Solve problems by analyzing root causes and unintended consequences in a structured and collaborative manner.
• Understand and ulitise power, networks, and influencing tactics in social contexts.
• Critically evaluate discourse in its use/abuse of rhetorical techniques and be awareness of one’s own communication

column1: The MicroLabs for TAs course is aimed at TAs of ESE who completed basic didactic training.
The course consists of two steps. First, students participate in the following four Microlabs:
1. How to activate students in the tutorial
2. How to explain complex ideas in simple ways
3. How to utilize public speaking in a tutorial
Second, after participating in these four Microlabs students are asked to reflect on the feedback and overall learnings from this course.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How to activate students in the tutorial
- Deliver the appropriate active teaching methods for your (online) tutorial
- Reflect on your own strengths and improvements in delivering an activating teaching method in your own education
How to explain complex ideas in simple ways
-Deliver multiple levels of explanation of the same concept
How to utilize public speaking in the tutorial
- Reflect on own use of non-verbal communication
- Apply basic rhetorical tools to an educational presentation
- Manage difficult situations that might occur within a tutorial group
- Adjust own teaching style to different student groups</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course can help you to become more effective and to reach your goals and aspirations. First of all, you learn how to prioritize your tasks and activities and how to efficiently organise your inbox, agenda and to do-list.
We will also introduce you to various working styles and discuss what the pro's and con's of each are, especially in times of stress.

You will also learn to use your own energy sustainably and how you can recharge through active and passive forms of renewal. Last, you will explore your values and aspirations, create scenarios for your future career, and set your own personal goals.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• You learn how to prioritize your tasks and activities and how to efficiently organize your inbox, agenda and to-do-list. You learn more about your working style(s), how to use the strengths that come with it and to recognize the pitfalls that arise in times of stress.

• You will understand why the sustainable use of your own energy is key to high performance. You know how to differentiate between your physical, emotional and mental capacity and how to recharge through active and passive forms of renewal.

• You will explore your values and aspirations and create scenarios for your future career. You will also learn how to set personal goals in order to bridge the gap between aspirations and productivity.
