column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In many organisations, working on projects will be part of your daily task. In this course will learn you how to become an effective project manager. You will learn what the core tasks of a project leader are, how to define and meet project requirements, goals and deliverables, and how to set up a project (including planning, divisions of labour, key deliverables and risk assessment). You will also learn more about the role you prefer to take when working in a team. You will be introduced to several team role theories. We will then focus on the 9 Belbin team roles and you will fill in a self-assessment questionnaire to explore your own team role preference.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• You learn more about the topics that are fundemental to each project and the three roles that need to be fulfilled
• You learn what your core tasks are as a project leader and what tasks should be delegated or ignored
• You understand the difference between project requirements, goals and deliverables and you know how to define these
• You learn to assess whether an assignment can be turned in to a project and you learn how to set up a project (including planning, divisions of labour, key deliverables and risk assessment)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is a mandatory part of the Career Skills programme. All bachelor-2 students (and bachelor-3 students who still need to do this course) will be added to this course by default. To finalise your registration you must attend the online kick-off of the course. If you do not attend, you will automatically be deregistered.
The aim of Your Future Career is to prepare students at an early stage in their studies for their career.

When you care about what you do, you will enjoy your work more, create greater impact, and be more successful. However, it can be difficult to identify what your passion is, where your competencies and skills will be useful, and which professional environment and culture are the best match for you. Therefore, the Career Skills programme offers you a course to put you in the driver's seat of your career, and to support you in identifying your first career step and preparing for it.

The online modules of Your Future Career will help you make crucial steps towards the most suitable internship or job for you. To pass the course you need to gain 50 points by a set deadline. You can decide yourself if you want to reflect on your interests and motivations, develop knowledge of the job market, functions, organisations and industries, or receive peer feedback on your application materials.
This course will run from the start of block 3 till the end of block 4. You cannot start halfway the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: - Assess own individual professional profile in larger community
- Show pro-activity in regard to career preparation
- Analyse your strengths and weaknesses, personality, values and skills
- Identify different career paths in the job market
- Identify career preparation gaps and create action points to fill the gaps
- Understand the recruitment and application process in different industries
Develop and learn to communicate your personal brand
- Assess how your future career can be a force for positive change
- Demonstrate written and verbal communication skills needed in the job application process</body>

If you started your bachelor in 2018-2019 or earlier, Career Skills is not a mandatory programme for you. You can still follow one of the courses in this programme, for instance if you need one more credit to finish your bachelor. To register, send an email to careerskills@ese.eur.nl.

Note that, except for the course FEB13901(X) Your Future Career, all courses have limited places available. Students for whom Career Skills is mandatory have precedence when subscribing to Career Skills courses. </body>

column1: Navigating organizational and societal change is a fundamental theme in the social sciences. Its relevance for managers grows with challenges that arise from coping with competitive markets, shifting societal values, environmental regulations, and evolving technologies. As you advance in your career, and assume greater responsibilities, you will need to drive necessary change in your organizations. You as potential leaders must, with increasing urgency, encourage other people to engage with change. Yet, this is easier said than done as exemplified by high numbers of initiatives failing to produce the intended results in practice. The necessity for managing change seems obvious, theories and tools for navigating change are elusive. The objective of this course is, hence, to holistically explore how change works in organizations. In the first part of the course, we will build on current theories and discuss how five interrelated processes — diagnosing, envisioning, assessing, designing, and intervening — may help to better think through and navigate the complexity of organizational changes. In the second part of the course, you will deep dive into societal megatrends as drivers of change and reflect on how environmental regulations and shifting societal values drive change in organizations. Taken together, the course aims to enable the students to develop an evidence-based mind-set on managing change. This course completes the business developer track.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Understand and explain core theories and models in the area of organizational change (content-related)
• Differentiate and apply concepts related to the diagnosing, envisioning, assessing, designing, and intervening processes during organizational change (skill-related)
• Adopt an evidence-based mindset to design recommendations to navigate change in organizations (attitude-related)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98886,2021,Changing Business Strategically,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. K Kavusan', 'dr. MG Baaij', 'dr. P Darnihamedani', 'dr. S Liu']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In addition to formulating a competitive strategy that leverages a firm`s competencies, it is also important to update the strategy in response to developments that change the dynamics of competition. The fast pace of innovation requires firms to constantly upgrade their product and service offerings to remain competitive and be ambidextrous: firms should not only focus on exploiting their existing capabilities, but also on developing new and complementary competencies. Two important skills to strategically change a business is to deploy existing competencies in innovative ways, and to locate and benefit from external knowledge that will facilitate new innovations. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge and skills about navigating an increasingly complex innovation landscape and to practice it through case discussions and group exercises. Throughout the course there will be a healthy mix of theory and its application in real-life situations.

The course consists of theory and skills sessions. In theory sessions, we will focus on theories that can form the basis for strategic change. We will discuss both theories and their application on real-life situations. In skills sessions we will focus on developing the skills that enable the formation and execution of innovative strategies. In addition to individual study, you will form teams to work on a team project in which you will apply the theories and skills you learned in the course to a real-life case. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After finishing this course students will be able to:

column2: • Formulate action plans to revise strategies in response to developments that change the dynamics of competition;
• Develop ideas to revise a company’s business model to leverage the core competencies of the firm in innovative ways;
• Appraise the value of external knowledge for innovation and identify appropriate sources for valuable external knowledge;
• Distinguish between exploration and exploitation and evaluate the role of each in enhancing competitiveness through innovation;
• Define a firm`s innovation ecosystem and describe the role of complementary external parties in developing new strategies to maintain competitive advantage;
• Analyze: (a) developments that change the dynamics of competition; and (b) ideas to leverage the core competencies of the firm in innovative ways;
• Create, evaluate and make decisions about options for new strategies and business models to: (a) respond to changing dynamics of competition; and (b) leverage core competencies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course traces the genealogy of the seven 'cheap' things that have made our modern
world: nature, money, work, care, food, energy and lives. Capitalism cannot exist without these
In examining the seven cheaps, the course provides a new understanding of capitalism as a -
of power, capital and nature. greatest strength and the source of its problems
is its capacity to make the world cheap and safe for itself: by creating and mobilizing geological,
botanical, animal and human forces and putting them to work as cheaply as possible.
However, the web of life cannot exist in a world-ecology designed by and for capitalism. Tracing
the history and practices of resistance by slaves, women, indigenous people, workers, animals and
other actants in the web of life, the course outlines a program of resistance (i.e., a way of thinking
beyond the cheap things and strategies that ecology has spawned) that includes
recognition, reparation, redistribution, reimagination and recreation.
Drawing on cutting-edge ecological research, feminist philosophy, heterodox political economics,
post-colonial theory and following Jason W. groundbreaking work on capitalism as worldecology,
this course proposes a radical new way of

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After this course, students will be able to:
- Conceptually define colonialism, neo-colonialism, imperialism and postcolonialism.
- Understand and describe some of the major ideas in postcolonialism, like Edward Said's Orientalism.
- Understand and describe some of the major theoretical debates within postcolonialsm.
- Understand and describe some of the concepts that are linked to decolonisation of culture, land and the mind.
- Understand and describe the present-day relevancy of the vantages that postcolonialism offers.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus ben je in staat om naast bovengenoemde punten, ongeveer 160 woorden in Pinyin te schrijven en ken je 20 Chinese basiskarakters. Daarnaast beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat, waarmee je eenvoudige zinnen leert formuleren waarmee je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is beginners 1, vergelijkbaar met het A1.1 niveau van het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Let op: deze cursus wordt op de campus gegeven.
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Chinees. (Oktober-december/januari-maart/april-juni)
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Chinees gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Over the past few decades, scholars from multiple disciplines (psychology, economics, organizational behaviour and marketing) have gained deeper insight into how consumers make choices, including the non-economic features of the choice environment that can influence people’s choices (e.g., default decisions, displayed font). Many of these insights have challenged the traditional assumption that people make choices primarily in a rational, self-interested manner. These research programs have provided novel insight into how people deviate from “optimal” choices and the consequences of these “sub-optimal” choices.

Because these decision strategies and mindsets often lead to choices that have harmful consequences for business, society and consumer welfare, it is important that students as future business leaders a) understand the basic principles of consumer decision making and b) have the tools to implement strategies that change consumer choice in the desired manner (dubbed nudging). Doing so will help them in numerous ways, including (but not limited to): a) making them a better decision maker in your personal and professional life, b) improving their ability to attract and retain satisfied customers and c) ensuring that their business runs smoothly.

Although there may be some overlap with contents typically seen in marketing courses on communication and advertising, Choice Architecture course provides a substantially different approach to understanding and changing consumer choice. Specifically, the current course will draw primarily from behavioural economics research, will be geared towards making sustainable choices at the individual, business, and societal levels, and will be aimed at developing choice-intervention strategies that can be implemented in a wide variety of contexts: one-on-one negotiations, team organization, risk management, policy design, among others, as well as more classic communication arenas such as social marketing.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Recognize core tenants of normative and descriptive models of choice
• Recognize core tenants of dual-process theories of cognition
• Be able to differentiate between different types of heuristics
• Be able to differentiate between different types of systematic biases
• Analyse novel decision contexts to figure out what aspects of the decision context lead to peoples’ current choices.
• Evaluate the monetary and psychological costs of the intervention
• Debate whether the intervention is ethical or not.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100140,2021,Cinema and Society,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: An industry, a media and an art, cinema is mostly enjoyed as a form of entertainment. Studying movies, unlike literature or painting, is often seen as a waste of time and an anomaly in higher education. Yet, the power of cinema to convince, to move audiences, and to provide influential stories should be carefully studied. This course will use several movies to understand their social significance, and how societies have replaced ancient mythologies with modern images.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Using a combination of case studies and film history, Cinema and Society intends to help students appreciate cinema and its effects on societies. Movies from different eras and societies will be used to provide students with a better understanding of cinema.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100142,2021,Cinemas in Context,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Each week in “Cinemas in Context”, a different movie will be analyzed to understand its roots, context, place in pop culture, and future in high culture. Focus will be on movies able to create their own universe, hence the subtitle “Deep universes”. Using a combination of students’ research, lecturing and tutoring, the seminar aims to contribute to a better understanding of cinema from an academic and artistic point of view. At the end of the seminar, students will be able to understand several movies’ universes provided in the curriculum, along with some they will choose themselves.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>""Cinemas in Context: Deep Universes"" intends to contribute to the understanding of film studies by exposing students to in-depth research in cinema as an art and an expression of culture.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/101575,2021,Circular Economy and implementing “Positive Impact”,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['DMPE den Held, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With the Circular Economy elective, you are taking the next step in sustainability strategies.
Where most sustainability strategies today still focus on reducing a company’s negative footprint, in this course we will also look at making a pósitive footprint.

Academically, this can be referred to as ‘regenerative sustainable development’. For business it means: instead of adding a burden to doing business as usual, we’re implementing a positive agenda to company strategies, business partnerships and customer relationships.

An exiting and existing example is paint that cleans the air (produced by AkzoNobel), and during this course, we will look at several other examples in the market today and discuss concepts for the future. We will look into the business benefits ánd obstacles of implementing these alternative project and/or company strategies.

Would you prefer to make a great business out of contributing to society and the environment, rather than just postponing the damage a company has on the environment or people? Then you are welcome to step into the Triple Top Line paradigm; the core of our theories and practice.
You are happily invited to step forward with a daring proposal for your roadmap assignment, fiery debates in the lectures and bold ideas during the exercises.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
Work with the Triple Top Line. You will not only learn and discuss the theoretic fundaments, but also actively practice it.
Implement the Triple Top Line in a company and/or project with a TTL ambitions text, TTL goals, transitional goals and a (strategic) roadmap.
You will go through this in exercises and work out an example in your individual assignment.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105546,2021,Circular Economy: Strategies & Business Models,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. P Morseletto, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Circular Economy has rapidly become a buzzword, but it is not always clear how it should affect corporations, organizations, or society as a whole.

This course aims to bring conceptual clarity and develop practical knowledge of circular solutions. The Circular Economy is then explored from both an applied and theoretical perspective while looking at strategies, foundational ideas, and business models. Several examples and case studies will illustrate different views on the Circular Economy, including barriers and enabling conditions.

The course consists of in-class lectures, some of which given by guest lecturers from the government or innovative companies, as well as three assignments: An in-class group presentation and short group report– both based on real business cases – and an individual report.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understanding the fundamental ideas, concepts, principles, barriers/enabling conditions, strategies, applications and business models of the circular economy.

column1: Foundational information technologies, in particular, Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms, Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, and Blockchain infrastructure, will create new foundations for business and its interaction among businesses, governments, customers, and the earth. These technologies will create opportunities for circular business models, i.e., to do business within the ecological and planetary boundaries of the earth. Instead of the ‘take, make, and dispose’ attitude of the traditional and linear business, circular business will create value with the design of ‘recycle, refurbish, reuse, and maintain’ processes. Both the circular and digital transformation will influence customer relationships, redefine products and services, change the operations and value chain processes, enable new ways of collaboration in business ecosystems, and will shift the information frontier further, with fresh, fast, and more reliable information relevant for circular business models. Next generation business models will need to develop both the circular and digital capabilities in a holistic configuration of people, processes, and technologies.  </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first goal of the course is to provide students with a better understanding of the differences between linear and circular business and between digitizing and digital business. Different circular processes, i.e., recycle, refurbish, reuse, and maintenance, are explained and different business models and business examples are discussed. Special attention will be paid to potential information needs and the provision of information by three foundational information technologies, e.g., AI, IoT, and Blockchain.

The second goal of the course is for students to learn how to analyze and evaluate circular and digital business models in such a way that three performance dimensions will improve, i.e., people (customers, employees, partners), planet (natural resources), and prosperity of the local and global society.
Examples in floriculture, energy, manufacturing, retail, trade and transport will be discussed.
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • Understand and explain the importance of circular and digital business within the social foundation and ecological ceiling of the Earth.
• Analyze and evaluate the circular and digital design dimensions of business models

• Understand and identify the circular information needs and the provision of these needs by foundational information technologies, in particular, Artificial Intelligence (AI) algorithms, Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems, and Blockchain infrastructure.
• Understand and apply the circular and digital business design knowledge in real-life business cases.

column1: Instructors: Prof. S.J.G. van Wijnbergen (UvA), Prof. F. van der Ploeg (Oxford Un, UvA)

This course focuses on climate change: one of the greatest challenges of our time. What can the science of economics teach us about its causes and potential solutions? What are the costs and benefits of climate change? Its impact on poverty? Should we tax carbon, cap-and-trade emission rights, or subsidize solar and wind power? Does the answer depend on how we value the future? Why/when should we discount the distant future less than the proximate future? What is the impact of risk and true uncertainty (ambiguity) on the discount rate? Can a tradeoff between growth and the environment be avoided, and if so with what sort of policies? Does trade harm the environment? Will our industry move abroad if we take a leading role and 'go it alone'? Can well-intended climate policies actually accelerate global warming? What are good second-best climate policies? How to deal with climate tipping points? What is the international incidence of climate change and of the climate policies needed to combat it? Why is it so difficult to negotiate international agreements?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After having completed this course, you will know the answers to the above questions, or at least you will be able to have an informed opinion; and you will be able to enter into the economic policy debate well informed.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Climate change is one of today’s most pressing issues, receiving international attention from political leaders, corporations, the media, advocacy groups, and the general public. In the future, it is likely to become even more pressing as the effects of climate change intensify resource competition, natural disasters, disease vectors, water and food scarcity, and refugee migration.

According to Sir Nicholas Stern, former chief economist of the World Bank, the impact of climate change is likely to change the international business environment dramatically. However, the business relevance of climate change is insufficiently understood by future decision makers in international management and society.

We believe that tomorrow’s business leaders should be educated on the key elements of climate change –the science, the evolving policy, and role of business. They can become an essential part of the solution, but only if equipped with a sound understanding of the challenges at hand and the processes by which new policies are constructed.

The Climate Change Strategy course and its Model United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) form an innovative educational approach to closing this knowledge gap. Our goal is to broaden students' understanding of climate change, climate policy, and their impacts on the future of business.

The course modules deal with the core issues of climate change and include a wide range of effective didactic tools and exercises. Students are given a deeper understanding of the background and consequences of climate change for business, and of corporate responses to it. Special emphasis is laid on international and national regulatory frameworks, and on emerging resource challenges and market opportunities. Furthermore, the course will provide students with an opportunity to develop a broad set of personal skills such as negotiation, forming strategy, research, public speaking and debating.

The 2021edition of the course will be simultaneously offered at eight leading CEMS universities and culminates in a two-day UNFCCC simulation event at one of the business schools. Students will be using the 2015 Paris Agreement created at COP21 and be simulating the upcoming COP27. Negotiations will seek to enhance the current Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) of countries and work out details of how the new mechanisms and funds will function. The big challenge is how to improve the current commitments to be in line with the universally agreed target of limiting global temperature rise to ‘well-below 2 degrees’.

Students will negotiate on issues such as mitigation of greenhouse gases (new voluntary targets, financing and compliance), adaptation to climate change (financing, climate change refugees, technology transfer), and market mechanisms (sustainable development mechanism, REDD+, aviation and shipping).
Students should attend and actively participate in the classes. Students are expected to engage in class discussions, ask questions of speakers, and demonstrate involvement with group exercises.
This course assumes no prior knowledge of climate change or of climate change policy. The course is divided into four modules:

column2: • Module 1 gives an extensive introduction to the topic of climate change and climate policy and will include a guest lecture from a notable climatologist.
• Module 2 will highlight the role of business in climate change and will include a guest speakers from industry.

• Module 3 prepares students for the role-play including negotiation skills training. Students gain insights in negotiation theory and acquire skills of looking beyond positions to the underlying interest of a party.
• Module 4 consists of an online simulation with all participating universities.

column1: Midterm, roles for the negotiation simulation will be assigned to all students. In line with the innovative three-sector approach of this course, each student will either represent a government delegate, a non-governmental organization or a lobbyist from industry. This approach aims to provide experience not only in inter-governmental debate of climate change issues, but also in the way civil society and business interests can influence these discussions.
Example blog of the Role Play in 2016, written by the fictitious media team: https://unfcccnegotiations2016.wordpress.com

column1: At the end of this module the participant is able to:

column2: • Understand the negotiation process under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
• Explain the roles and interests of the private sector, government and civil society in tackling climate change.
• Formulate a negotiation strategy for climate change negotiations.
• Apply negotiation skills in an international negotiations setting

column1: <body>The ability to communicate effectively is very important for many professional practitioners. Professional communication differs from normal communication in a number of ways, for example by using professional interviews. Professional interviews have a clear purpose and how the interview is led and carried out should be geared towards achieving that goal. Good problem clarification, for example, is a condition of a good professional therapy or advice session. Furthermore, the client can expect that a professional takes the greatest care in dealing with his or her personal problems, which can be very sensitive issues. A number of basic communication skills and a good basic attitude are needed in order to achieve this goal. So, the aim of this course is to improve the knowledge and skills required for effective communication. Theory and research on communication is reviewed and basic attitudes and basic interviewing skills are practised in role-plays. Note. This course is not about the clinical interview as a tool for diagnosing clients.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The Clinical Communication Skills course will:

column5: Help you gain insight into the processes in counselling a person with a request for help.
Help you gain insight into and knowledge of the Van der Molen, Lang, Trower & Look (2014) interview model and how to use this model
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the concrete skills needed to help a person with a problem
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the adequate use of these interviewing skills

Deepen your knowledge in cultural differences that exist between (counsellors and) clients in perceptions of mental illnesses and help you gain insight into the multicultural counseling competencies needed to help clients from different cultures.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The WHO (Geneva, 2001) estimated that 450 million people will suffer from a mental or neurological illness at some point in their lives. That’s about 1 in every 4 people. Due to this 1 in 4 prevalence of mental illness, it is very likely that most of us know or have met someone who has been diagnosed with a mental illness. In this course, we’ll cover some of the main and more commonly occurring and diagnosed mental disorders as they appear in the DSM5. We’ll take a look at how these disorders are viewed from the traditional psychiatric perspective as well as how mental illness is viewed from other perspectives in the field of psychology, not only in terms of their causes, but also in terms of how they are described, understood and applied by practitioners in the field. By the end of the course, students will have gained an understanding of the scope of the field of clinical psychology, including how working in the field is not always as black and white as it may first appear.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: On completion of this course, students need to be able to:

column5: Have a basic understanding of the role of clinical assessment in the field of mental health

Know the basic documented history of mental illness and the field of clinical psychology, including the different models of understanding of mental illness and the causes of mental illness. Identify the diagnostic criteria for the specific disorders covered in the course (lectures and PBL activities)
Have and understanding of the DSM-5: it’s history, it’s organization and the main changes to the current edition, including the dimensional approach to mental illness diagnosis
Understand the diagnostic process and the concept of co-morbidity
Understand the role of culture in understanding and interpreting mental illness and mental health
Have a grasp of the overlap and differences between psychology and psychiatry

Develop a critical perspective on the field of clinical psychology, including having developed their own opinions (based on the course material) of what mental illness and mental health are, as well as what might distinguish abnormality from normality and how the field may or may nog contribute to stigma and discrimination

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Angststoornissen behoren tot de meest voorkomende psychiatrische stoornissen en kennen vele verschijningsvormen: zo zijn er de specifieke fobie, sociale fobie, paniekstoornis, agorafobie, gegeneraliseerde angststoornis, obsessief-compulsieve stoornis en de posttraumatische stress stoornis. De studenten zullen de verschillende angststoornissen van elkaar moeten kunnen onderscheiden. Daarnaast is het de bedoeling dat studenten het ontstaan van deze stoornissen kunnen verklaren: daartoe dienen ze niet alleen te beschikken over grondige kennis van algemene conditioneringprincipes, maar ook oog te hebben voor meer specifieke processen die bij iedere stoornis apart een rol spelen.

Stress is een belangrijk thema binnen de gezondheidspsychologie. In dit blok zal vooral worden stilgestaan bij de relatie tussen stress enerzijds en lichamelijke en geestelijke gezondheidsproblemen. Denk daarbij aan hart- en vaatziekten, kanker, en maagzweren, maar ook aan depressie en angststoornissen zoals de paniek- en de post-traumatische stress stoornis.

Studenten maken in dit blok kennis met persoonlijkheidsdiagnostiek. In dit blok oefenen de studenten met de Eysenck Personality Profiler (EPP). Verwacht wordt dat studenten zelf de EPP invullen, scoren, en hun profiel in verband brengen met normgegevens en een persoonsbeschrijving door een naaste. Tot slot dienen studenten hier op correcte wijze verslag van te leggen, waarbij er ook aandacht is voor zelfreflectie.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: De algemene doelstelling van dit blok is de aanwezige kennis van angststoornissen en stress te verdiepen en uit te breiden.
Specifiek kunnen de volgende doelen voor dit blok worden geformuleerd:

column5: Kennis hebben van biologische en psychologische processen die betrokken zijn bij stress en de ervaring er van.
Kennis hebben van de fenomenologie, de symptomatologie en de DSM-classificatie van de angststoornissen.
Kennis hebben van de etiologie van deze stoornissen.
Kennis hebben van de psychologische en farmacologische behandeling van angststoornissen.
In staat zijn om wetenschappelijke artikelen over psychische stoornissen kritisch te lezen en samen te vatten.
Kennis hebben van het interpreteren van een persoonlijkheidsvragenlijst aan de hand van normgegevens.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: De klinische psychologie richt zich op afwijkend, slecht aangepast of abnormaal gedrag dat door individuen zelf of hun omgeving als ongewenst wordt gezien. Men spreekt in dit verband ook wel van psychische, psychiatrische of psychopathologische stoornissen, of kortweg van psychopathologie. Deze stoornissen zijn veelal het resultaat van een samenspel van biologische, psychologische en sociale factoren. In aansluiting hierop houdt de klinische psychologie zich bezig met vraagstukken als 'Hoe ontstaan psychische stoornissen?', 'Hoe komt het dat ze blijven voortbestaan?', 'Welke verschillende stoornissen zijn er te onderscheiden?' en 'Op welke manieren kunnen psychopathologische stoornissen worden verholpen of voorkomen?'. Binnen dit blok gaan we in op de uiteenlopende verschijningsvormen van psychische stoornissen, op de theorieën over het ontstaan en voortduren van deze stoornissen en op de verschillende behandelingen en hun effectiviteit.
De kernvragen die gedurende het blok steeds weer aan de orde zullen komen zijn: waar ligt de grens tussen normaal en abnormaal, hoe ontstaat een stoornis en wat is er aan te doen?
Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het blok "Normaal of abnormaal?" gaat over afwijkend gedrag van mensen en     geeft     een     inleiding     in     het     vakgebied     van     de     klinische     psychologie.     Aan     de     hand     van     voorbeelden     uit     de     praktijk     worden     belangrijke     psychische     stoornissen     bestudeerd,     waaronder     angststoornissen,     eetstoornissen,     stemmingsstoornissen     en     psychotische     stoornissen.     Na     afloop     van     het     blok     kent     de     student     van     de     meest     voorkomende     stoornissen     het     klinisch     beeld     en     de     diagnostische     criteria,     de     theorieën     over     etiologie     alsmede     de     empirische     bevindingen     die     de     theorie     steunen     dan     wel     tegenspreken,     de     gangbare     therapieën     en     de     effectiviteit     daarvan.

column1: <body>In this course, which will be taught in Dutch, you will acquire the basic skills required to establish and lead a consultation as a physician. The course consists of two types of sessions that overlap Quads 1, 2, 3 and 4 of year 3: (1) Clinical reasoning (Klinisch redeneren, KR) and (2) Consultation (Consultvoering, CV). During the clinical reasoning sessions, you will learn how to make a diagnosis, after examining and analysing a patient’s complaints. You will learn what the importance is of knowing what kind of questions the physician should ask to obtain crucial and relevant information. In addition, you will learn which diseases can be the cause of a specific complaint, and how to make an accurate diagnosis by physical examinations and diagnostic tests. In the Consultation sessions, you will be able to practice the aforementioned skills. You will learn how to approach and interview patients, how to perform a physical examination, and how to interpret your findings. Due to the practical nature of the course, the assessment will be based mainly on practical exams performed in Quad 4.</body>

- Establish and lead an anamnesis as a physician

column1: This course spans the entire academic year - starting quad 1 and ending quad 4. During the course we come together for seven sessions in a seminar setting (mixing ‘close reading’ and ‘discussion’) with space for pedagogical experimentation to read - from cover to cover - one of the key works in critical pedagogy by scholar, educator and activist bell hooks: Teaching to Transgress (1994). In this book, hooks, whose writings are situated in the interstices of race, gender, class and education through a black feminist lens, writes from her experiences with racism and sexism as a student and her own teaching practice to propose ‘education as the practice of freedom’ and the inclusive classroom as a transgressive space for change.

column1: In this course you will study the mental processes involved in digital media processing. Four basic cognitive functions will be covered:

Among the topics that will be addressed are the following. Do people have an attentional bias for negative information? Do people forget information once it has been discredited? To what extent does conspiracy thinking rely on the same mechanisms we use to comprehend information? Why are the digital media a fertile soil for the spread of misinformation and conspiracy theories? How do our cognitive biases impact our social media use? In what ways can scientists research these issues? How can we minimize the negative impact of digital media messages on our cognitive system?</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The main objective of this course is for you to gain a basic understanding of the interaction between cognitive processes and the digital media. Students will be introduced to important theories behind basic cognitive processes, such as attention, memory, comprehension, and thinking. You will become familiar with empirical research on digital media use that is informed by these theories to address questions concerning topics such as misinformation, desinformation, conspiracy thinking, and thinking biases, as well as how to counter the negative impact of these processes.  At the end of this course, you will be familiar with major theories of cognitive information processing. You will be able to apply these theories to aspects of digital media use and thus acquire an understanding of digital media processing. You will have learned how psychologists conduct a variety of research tools, including surveys, experiments, and data mining, to understand how the digital media affect our thought processes. Furthermore, you will gain experience in critically evaluating research on cognition and the digital media. Finally, you will be able to think about  ways in which the potential negative impact of the digital media on our thought processes can be mitigated.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Cognitive neuroscience studies the cognitive and neural basis for such diverse mental functions as perception, action, language, attention and memory. This relatively young discipline seeks to unravel the workings of the brain. What happens in our brains when we do what we do? How is this fascinating, unbelievably complex 'microcosmos' inside our skulls organised? How do those billions of nerve cells collaborate in an organ no bigger than half a football? Thanks to advanced brain-imaging techniques available today, scientists are able to observe the human brain in action, while animal studies provide an unsurpassed understanding of underlying mechanisms. As many already know, cognitive neuroscience is the discipline of the future.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course, the student can

column5: apply knowledge about basic neuroscience anatomy and physiology;
relate cognitive phenomena to biological processes;
distinguish the different forms of memory and their biological basis;
describe the neurological processes involved in sleep/waking transition
describe the hierarchy in decision making and its biological basis;
describe the mechanisms behind overt and covert attention;
describe the neural mechanisms behind emotions;
relate evolutionarily primitive neural reward mechanisms to human sexual behaviour
conduct behavioural experiments in a cognitive neuroscience context;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We have nearly 8 billion people on earth, and all of us think. But why do we think? How do we think? And what happens if we stop thinking?

This course explores the answers to these profound questions. It will go further than the course ‘Brain & Behaviour’ as it will introduce concepts like schemas, mental imagery, categorisation and language, to understand how the content of thoughts are established. Furthermore, this course delves into memory and attention. In addition, it will introduce the study of complex thinking abilities, such as problem solving, reasoning and decision making, and looks at the deterioration of cognitive processes: What happens if we are unable to think properly?

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98690,2021,Cognitive Psychology: Thinking and Remembering,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['AM Hoekstra, MSc', 'dr. SKA Verheyen']",,"Inhoud

Menselijke cognitie kan beschouwd worden als een snelle weg waarlangs wij ons aan veranderende omstandigheden in onze omgeving aanpassen, naast de tragere methoden van genetische mutatie en (operant) leren. Hoe helpt aandacht ons efficiënt met de informatie uit onze externe en interne omgeving om te gaan, en wat gebeurt er als aandacht faalt? Kennis en kennisrepresentatie vormen een tweede thema. Relevante vragen daarbij zijn: op welke wijze beelden wij informatie uit onze omgeving innerlijk af en hoe gebruiken we de kennis bij het interpreteren van de wereld om ons heen? De structuur en het functioneren van onze geheugens is een derde onderwerp. Hoe wordt informatie onthouden voor de korte en lange termijn? Wat gebeurt er als we herinneringen ophalen? Het laatste thema betreft redeneren en denken. Zijn er wetmatigheden te onderkennen in ons redeneren? Hoe denkt de expert en hoe de beginner in een bepaald domein?

Het blok biedt een introductie in de centrale onderwerpen van de cognitieve psychologie. Hierbij spelen cognitieve processen als begrijpen, kennisverwerving en kennisrepresentatie, aandacht, herinneren, denken, en probleemoplossen een centrale rol. Studenten maken kennis met het klassieke model van het informatieverwerkende systeem dat aan deze processen ten grondslag ligt.

De lokalisatie, lateralisatie en organisatie van de verschillende hersenfuncties zullen worden behandeld. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de gehanteerde technieken, variërend van diermodellen tot humaan beeldvormend onderzoek zoals bijvoorbeeld met functionele MRI. column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98941,2021,Collaboration Africa,Engels, Nederlands","Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. RJM van Tulder', 'R Reshef, MA']",,"Inhoud

This subject builds on knowledge accumulated in the first two subjects. The goal is to strengthen African partnerships network, and develop sustainable project planning skills. The online learning environment forms an integral part of this course, which consists out of three modules.

Module I: A Small Private Online Course (SPOC): A Critical Engagement with Advancing the SDGs (6 ECs) aims to develop critical, transdisciplinary and innovative approaches to sustainable development. It is offered as a global classroom with invited guest students from African-based higher institutions.

Module II: A three week Africa field study (5 ECs) is the integrative focal point of this minor to experience what students have learnt in a real-life situation. If travel is allowed by the universities, students can choose between participating in a structured visit to Kenya, Morocco, or South Africa. This module is self-funded, and students who cannot or do not want to partake in the field study abroad, can complete this module in the Netherlands.

Module III: Building Networks (4 ECs) aims to enables students to continue building their own network through participating in a series of webinars and excursion with key stakeholder and partners which inform EU-Dutch-African relations.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Many groups (e.g., countries, juries, families) take important collective decisions via voting methods. Examples include parliamentary and presidential elections, or juries in sport and court. Typically group members have different preferences. Can individual preferences be aggregated into a consistent collective choice? Will collective choice respect normative values shared by the members? This course will cover the main principles of Social and Collective Choice in theory and practice to answer these questions. We will study different voting methods, their properties, and how they affect voting outcomes. Theoretically, the course will introduce a framework of analysis for aggregating individual preferences into a collective decision. Empirically, the course will present many interesting real-life cases that put theory into practice. Finally, the course will present a behavioral perspective on Social Choice and Collective decisions. The theoretical part is mostly based on the assumption that individual members act rationally. Yet, how do people vote in practice? What psychological factors are important to consider? To enhance the behavioral part, the course will present the insights from recent experiments and field studies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will learn the core concepts of Social Choice Theory.
• Students will learn the core concepts of Behavioral Social Choice.
• Students will learn about current voting methods, alternative voting methods, and how they affect election outcomes.
• Students will learn to analyze electoral systems and to understand how different aspects of an electoral system shape electoral competition.
• Student will learn a theoretical framework that will help them understand why so many seemingly paradoxical election results are observed in the real world.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99017,2021,Combinatorial Optimisation,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. W van den Heuvel'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Combinatorial optimisation deals with finding an optimal solution from a finite set of feasible solutions. Since enumerating this set is practically infeasible in general, one tries to exploit the problem structure to find an optimal solution in a computationally efficient way. In this course, we develop techniques for combinatorial optimisation problems. These techniques include:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To recognise and model combinatorial optimisation problems as integer programming problems.
• To understand the basic theory and techniques to solve integer programming problems.
• To master the basic techniques to solve some specific combinatorial optimisation problems.
• To be able to implement the basic solution techniques in a software package.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/99016,2021,Combinatorisch optimaliseren,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. W van den Heuvel'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De combinatorische optimalisering houdt zich bezig met het vinden van een optimale oplossing uit een eindige verzameling van toegelaten oplossingen. Omdat volledige enumeratie van deze verzameling vaak onpraktisch is door het zeer grote aantal toegelaten oplossingen, probeert men gericht te zoeken naar een optimale oplossing door gebruik te maken van de aanwezige structuur. In dit college worden oplossingsmethoden voor combinatorische optimaliseringsproblemen behandeld. Technieken die worden behandeld zijn:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Het herkennen en modelleren van combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen als discrete optimaliseringsproblemen.
• Het begrijpen van de basistheorieën en -technieken om geheeltallige lineaire programmeringsproblemen op te lossen.
• Het beheersen van de basistechnieken voor het oplossen van een aantal specifieke combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen.
• In staat zijn de basisoplossingstechnieken toe te passen in een softwarepakket.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100842,2021,Commercial Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,"['dr. FL Stevens', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. W de Wit']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Commercial Law focuses on the contract of sale as the Master plan governing the organization of international commercial transactions. In it, the parties not only provide rules about when and where to deliver what quantity of which commodity for what price, but also for who should contract for transportation and insurance, as well as for payment and/or financing of the commercial transaction. Together, all these commercial contracts build a cluster with dynamics of its own. A key role is played by the documents reflecting these contracts. To name a few, the Bill of Exchange, the Bill of Lading, the Insurance Policy or Insurance Certificate, the Letter of Credit and the Letter of Indemnity. All these documents convey the message that in international commerce, contracts generally involve and affect third parties. From the moment of issuance, most of these documents are meant to pass from hand to hand until they reach their final destination where they will play their part. Each contract has certain peculiarities in accordance with the requirements of international trade. Attention will be given to standardized contract forms and customary abbreviations such as CIF, FOB, CAD LC and so on. Other topics to be discussed include:
- The phenomenon of negotiability of documents;
- The various roles played by the bill of lading and the implications of the presentation rule;

- The abstract payment obligation of a bank under a letter of credit or a letter of undertaking and the so-called strict conformity rule as applied by banks in their handling of commercial documents: strict to the letter of their instructions;
- Insurance for the benefit of (as yet unknown) persons interested in the goods.

Much of international trade is subjected to international Conventions and powerful customs and standardized contracts, often subject to English law and London arbitration. As of consequence these international standards will form an important basis for our studies into commercial law.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After completion of this course, the student can interpret and analyse critically, the main aspects of an international commercial transaction in relation to sale of goods, documents of title, banking, transport, insurance and customs law according to English law and from a civil law perspective, taking into account important international uniform law conventions. Further, the student will be able to develop a personal point of view, enter into a discussion, observe and analyse important developments, with regard to this topic and is able to apply his knowledge, to a given set of facts (case).</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/100689,2021,Commodity Trade and Supply Networks,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['WAA Jacobs'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Commodities are critical in the global economy as they literally power the world, feed the planet and provide the essential inputs in all the devices (e.g. smartphones) and household appliances (e.g. shampoo) that make our lives easy. Commodity trading involves the transformation of commodities in time (through storage), space (through shipping) and form (through processing). Commodity trading firms (CTFs) such as Vitol, Trafigura and Cargill are for a large part responsible for the supply and delivery of commodities to their clients, often large manufacturing firms, in which they take upon (and offset) various forms of risks (e.g. price volatility, geopolitics, the weather, foreign currency exchange and operational risks such as delay in delivery) for their clients. Commodity trading thus involves highly dynamic information-intensive tasks and capabilities in the field of logistics, finance and technology.

No better place to study this than in Rotterdam: Europe’s gateway for the global trade in physical commodities. Rotterdam forms the heart of the ARA-region (Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp), a global price reference point for crude oil and used as geographical benchmark in many commodity delivery contracts and freight prices. Commodity traders make use of the port to ship the commodities to markets and many have actual logistical assets (tank storage and warehouses) and processing operations (i. c. refineries)  in the port in addition to the trade desks, supply chain support functions, head offices or holdings in the city.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to provide a clear understanding of the important role that commodity traders play in global supply chains and to gain both hard analytical skills and soft skills required to work in dynamic, multinational commodity trading operations.
After the course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand worldwide supply and demand patterns of the most important commodity product groups (energy, metals/minerals, agriculturals)

• Comprehend the way commodity markets (physical and derivative) function and the role that commodity trading firms play in the worldwide physical delivery of commodities, including contracting, financing and shipping.
• Comprehend the various forms of risks involved in commodity trading and how these can be mitigated.
• Analyze specific commodity markets and synthesize these analyses into (short term) trading strategies and (long term) strategic decision-making
• Present analytical results to a professional audience.

column1: The assessment consists of an individual assignment (essay), a group assignment (business case), and an individual written exam. The elective will be concluded with a College Tour-style meeting, in which students and business leaders will engage in thought provoking discussions.
